term.name: Absorb
term.definition: To drink in a substance. Almost any animals living in an aquatic or wetland habitats suffer more from pesticide exposure than animals living on dry land, primarily because wetland organisms absorb so much more pesticide from water.

term.name: Acaracides
term.definition: The pesticides used to control ticks.

term.name: Acetylcholinesterase
term.definition: Deactivates the messenger enzyme, acetylcholine, allowing animals to control voluntary muscles. When pesticides bind to acetylcholinesterase, muscle contractions can't be controlled.

term.name: Active Ingredients
term.definition: The chemical(s) in a product responsible for pesticidal activity; what makes the bug die!

term.name: Acute Toxicity
term.definition: A near-immediate reaction to a chemical that causes injury or even death from a single dose or exposure within 24 hours of the exposure.

term.name: Adjuvants
term.definition: Substance other than the active ingredient of a pesticide e.g., surfactant, spreader-sticker, or wetting agent, that enhances the coverage of a sprayed-on pesticide.

term.name: Adsorb
term.definition: To accumulate a substance on the surface in a condensed layer. Pesticides can make their way to lakes, rivers, and streams in two basic ways. They can hitch a ride with eroding soil by adsorbing, or attaching, to soil particles. Or, they can dissolve in runof water and move with the water as it flows across the surface.

term.name: Adsorption
term.definition: The clinging of molecules to the surface of particles. Water doesn't enter wood fibers, it just sticks to wood fibers.

term.name: Adulterated
term.definition: Containing added poisonous or harmful ingredients.

term.name: Aerosol
term.definition: A fine suspension of solid or liquid particles.

term.name: Agent
term.definition: (See Pathogen).

term.name: Agitation
term.definition: Process of stirring or mixing in a sprayer.

term.name: Air Force Institute for Occupational Health (AFIOH)
term.definition: Air Force Institute for Occupational Health: AFIOHs mission is to promote global health and protect Air Force (AF) warriors and communities by enhancing readiness and effectiveness by developing and implementing creative solutions to operational health problems using the range of tools available including environmental and health surveillance, risk analysis, and consultation.

term.name: Air plenum
term.definition: A space used to conduct air inside a structure.

term.name: Alate
term.definition: A winged, primary reproductive termite. (They fly out trying to mate; most die).

term.name: Algaecides
term.definition: Pesticides that kill algae.

term.name: Alkaloid
term.definition: Any of various organic compounds normally with basic chemical properties and usually containing at least one nitrogen atom in a heterocyclic ring, occurring chiefly in many vascular plants and some fungi. Many alkaloids, such as nicotine, quinine, cocaine, and morphine, are known for their poisonous or medicinal attributes.

term.name: Allelopathic
term.definition: A plant that suppresses the growth of another plant species due to the release of toxic substances

term.name: Allelopathy
term.definition: The production and release of chemical substances by one species that inhibit the growth of other species of plants.

term.name: Amino acid synthesis inhibitors
term.definition: Herbicides of this class inhibit plant protein formation. Such inhibition interferes with DNA synthesis and cell growth. Glyphosate, or Roundup, interferes with production of chlorophyll, as well as vital enzymes

term.name: Amplifying Host
term.definition: Disease recipient in which the pathogen multiplies and can be passed on. Also known as an incidental host

term.name: Analog (Synthetic analog)
term.definition: A chemical compound that is structurally similar to another but differs slightly in composition. Pyrethroids are synthetic analogs of the botanical, pyrethrum. Organic chemists have determined the structure of natural pyrethrum, the material derived from living chrysanthemums, and constructed similar molecules, with similar, and even superior, insecticidal properties

term.name: Anaphylactic Shock
term.definition: The most severe type of anaphylaxis; will usually lead to death in minutes if left untreated

term.name: Anaphylaxis
term.definition: A severe and rapid multi-system allergic reaction that occurs when a person is exposed to a trigger substance, called an allergen, to which they have become sensitized. Minute amounts of allergens may cause a life-threatening anaphylactic reaction. Anaphylaxis may occur after ingestion,inhalation, skin contact or injection of an allergen.

term.name: Angoumois grain moth
term.definition: Named after Angoumois, a region in France; a small moth, very destructive to wheat and other grain; the larva eats out the interior of the grain, leaving only the shell.

term.name: Annual
term.definition: Plant that lives only one season.

term.name: Antennal Club
term.definition: The very tip of the antenna; distinguishing trait for red and confused flour beetle. Seen under the microscope, the last 3 segments of the antennal club of the red flour beetle are markedly larger; for the confused flour beetle the last 4 segments are markedly larger.

term.name: Anterior
term.definition: Front part or in the front.

term.name: Anticoagulants
term.definition: Rodenticides that work by destroying the clotting power of the rodent's blood and damaging capillaries. (Example, the Coumarins of which Warfarin is an example; the Indandiones, of which diphacinone is an example).

term.name: Anti-fouling agent
term.definition: A wood preservative or paint, like tributyl tin oxide (TBTO), that prevents marine organisms (especially barnacles) from attaching to the hull of a ship. Use of TBTO near marine life is now banned.

term.name: Antihelminthics
term.definition: Category of chemicals used to kill nematodes (roundworms), trematodes (flatworms), and/or cestodes (tapeworms) in humans and animals.

term.name: Antivenin
term.definition: An antitoxin that counteracts the effects of venom from the bite of a snake, spider or venomous animal or insect.

term.name: Appropriated- fund activities
term.definition: Operations for which Congress appropriates funding.

term.name: Arachnids
term.definition: Any small animals with 8 legs, such as scorpions and spiders.

term.name: Aracides
term.definition: Pesticides that kill mites and ticks.

term.name: Araneaea
term.definition: An order the class Arachnida; about 105 families of spiders are known, plus about 10 that are extinct.

term.name: Arthropod
term.definition: Invertebrate with an exo-skeleton, jointed legs and segmented body, such as flies, moths, crabs and lobsters. The word arthropod is derived from the Greek words arthro, which means joint or segment, and poda, which means foot or appendage. (Many animals with a spinal cord (vertebrates) have a jointed foot, but arthropods are the only invertebrates (animals without a spinal cord) that have a jointed appendage).

term.name: Atomized
term.definition: Reduced to fine particles or a fine spray.

term.name: Attractant
term.definition: (1) A substance, such as food or a pheromone (a chemical secreted externally by an organism to send information to members of the same species), that attracts insects or other animals (2) Whatever lures a pest into a habitat, e.g., food, water, harborage (shelter). Chemical control involves the use of pesticides, baits, insect growth regulators, repellants and attractants. Sanitation, a part of facilities management, involves removing attractants, such as food scraps.

term.name: Augmentation contract
term.definition: specialized service that is contracted out and in support of an existing government pest management operation, such as: aerial applications, wood treatment, utility pole treatment, large-scale termiticide applications.

term.name: Automatic compensation
term.definition: The now defunct practice of reimbursing manufacturers when they got stuck with a big inventory of suspended or canceled dangerous pesticides.(FIFRA Lite, 1988, ended this practice.) Farmers and applicators may still apply for compensation, but not manufacturers.

term.name: Avermectins
term.definition: A complex of compounds derived from the soil fungus Streptomyces avermitilis. These pesticides were first introduced in the 1980s. Avermectins are slow acting stomach poisons that are quite persistent in the environment. These insecticides are primarily used as ant and cockroach baits, miticides, and antihelminthics.

term.name: Avicides
term.definition: Pesticides that kill birds.

term.name: Backflow
term.definition: A phenomenon in which water is siphoned into a water hose after water pressure drops throughout the system, thus flowing in reverse, or back.

term.name: Baffle
term.definition: A flat plate that controls or directs the flow of liquid or energy.

term.name: Bait
term.definition: Insecticide that works slowly and at relatively low doses, such that the social insect takes the insecticide back to the colony before dying.

term.name: Bait Shyness
term.definition: Phenomenon whereby a rodent only accepts the rodenticide bait the first time. Thereafter, they shun the bait because it is so clear to them that the bait kills. Many of the older rodenticides presented this problem.

term.name: Ballooning
term.definition: Larvae attach a strand of webbing to a twig and drop down several feet. The wind snaps the web and the larvae travels through the air on a parachute-like web.

term.name: Bare Ground Pest Control
term.definition: A pest control action that attempts to kill every living plant on an area of land. This strategy is best suited to industrial sites such as electrical transformer yards.

term.name: Barnacles
term.definition: Marine crustaceans with feathery food-catching appendages; free-swimming as larvae; as adults form a hard shell and live attached to submerged surfaces, such as rocks and ships' bottoms.

term.name: Bean Weevil
term.definition: One of two main pests of dry beans and peas (the other being the cowpea weevil). Adults attack legumes either in storage or in the field and may even completely destroy them. The grubs, or larvae, hatch from eggs laid in holes that have been chewed by the female into stored beans or into pods in the field.

term.name: Bethel process
term.definition: Also known as the full-cell process; a pressure and vacuum system designed to put the maximum preservative into wood.

term.name: Biennial
term.definition: Plant that lives 2 seasons.

term.name: Bilateral symmetry
term.definition: A type of body organization in which the left and right hand sides are essentially similar.

term.name: Bioaccumulation
term.definition: See Biomagnification.

term.name: Biocide
term.definition: Type of pesticide, such as creosote or pentachlorophenol, that kill most living things.

term.name: Bioinsecticides
term.definition: Insecticides derived from the living world. Bioinsecticides may be materials from long-dead organisms, like petroleum, or insecticides derived from living plants, like nicotine, or even living organisms, like bacteria and nematodes used as pesticides.

term.name: Biological Control
term.definition: (1) Reduction of pest populations by using living organisms encouraged by man (2) Reduction of pest populations through the use of living organisms encouraged by humans; this includes reproductive and genetic control, bacterial" and viral agents, and the use of predatory insects or mites.

term.name: Biological tools (IPM)
term.definition: Using living things encouraged by man to control pests (ladybug beetle are released to control aphids on plant).

term.name: Biological Vector
term.definition: A vector that carries a microorganism which goes through a cycle and replicates in vector and the host. (As opposed to a mechanical vector, like the house fly, which does not replicate the pathogen, but simply picks up a pathogen on its feet from feces and then deposits on human food.)

term.name: Biologically Active
term.definition: Substances that impact living organisms by causing some change. In the case of pesticides, the change is usually intended to be fatal. For example, some chemicals intended to kill rodents act by preventing blood clotting and by increasing capillary permeability, causing internal bleeding.

term.name: Biomagnification
term.definition: The process by which the concentration of a pollutant in animals is increased as it moves upward through the food chain (e.g., egret populations decline after DDT use to kill mosquito larva).

term.name: Biopesticide
term.definition: Biopesticides differ from traditional, synthetic, chemical pesticides because they are found in nature and affect pests by means other than toxicity. Instead of using a poison, a biopesticide controls the pest in other ways such as suffocation or starvation.

term.name: Biotic simplification
term.definition: reduction in biological complexity through the elimination of a vital component of an ecosystem. Pesticides may eliminate the natural controls and ecological balance provided by native predators and parasites, by eliminating these native predators and parasites.

term.name: Bird Flu
term.definition: Also known as avian flu, is a type of influenza virulent in birds. Public health officials have an enormous fear that a mutated strain will pass into the human population.

term.name: Bleb Formation
term.definition: A small swelling on the skin, akin to a blister, caused by a brown treesnake bite.

term.name: Book lungs
term.definition: Lung-like saccular breathing organs containing numerous thin folds of membrane arranged like the leaves of a book, as in the lungs of many arachnids.

term.name: Botanicals
term.definition: Pesticides, usually insecticides, derived from plant tissue. Examples include nicotine, an effective insecticide, and rotenone, an insecticide also used to kill pest fish species.

term.name: Broad Spectrum
term.definition: Used effectively to control many different types of pests.

term.name: Broad Toxicity
term.definition: When a pesticide kills not one, but a number of different types of pests. Example: Prevail, a pesticide used to kill grass, will also kill fish and invertebrates, thus the label warns against cleaning the hose into nearby waters.

term.name: Broadcast
term.definition: Method of spraying liquid residual pesticides over a wide areas of land or water. (Spraying an entire carpet is also a form of broadcast spraying.)

term.name: Brown Treesnake
term.definition: Nocturnal, strikes defensively when threatened; feeds on vertebrates, primarily, lizards, birds, and mammals. In Guam, where it was introduced, it has been implicated in the extinction of several vertebrate species, including all native birds.

term.name: Buboes
term.definition: Swollen lymph nodes, tell-tale symptom of bubonic plague, which appear 2-6 days after being bitten.

term.name: Bubonic plague
term.definition: A bacterial disease vectored by fleas; this was the cause of the Black Death in the Middle Ages.

term.name: Budding
term.definition: Means of colony propagation used by Pharaoh's ants and other species in which some reproductive adults and a group of workers splinter off the original colony to start a new one

term.name: Buffering agent
term.definition: A material added to a pesticide formulation or to the spray tank to modify the acidity or alkalinity so as to protect the active ingredient from breakdown

term.name: Calibrated cylinder
term.definition: A device used to measure liquid volumes. The cylinder is divided into units such as ounces or milliliters and centiliters (for metric measurements).

term.name: Calibration
term.definition: Any adjustment made to the equipment or spray mixture in order to apply a specific amount of pesticide to a given target site.

term.name: Calibration constant
term.definition: 5940; number used in the formula for converting gallons per acre (gpa) to gallons per minute; derived by obtaining the product of the square feet in an acre (43,560 square feet), the minutes in an hour and the inches in a foot, and dividing that product by the feet in a mile (5280).

term.name: Canceling
term.definition: In an equation, canceling, means to multiply and divide by the same number or unit. The result is one, which effectively, eliminates like parts of the equation.

term.name: Carbamates
term.definition: Along with organophosphates, carbamates are highly toxic and the most dangerous group of pesticides. Carbamates and organophosphates kill by cholinesterase inhibition, attack the nervous system, causing loss of muscular control. (Injuries from carbamates are more easily reversible than those of organophosphates.)

term.name: Carbon dioxide Sequestration
term.definition: The principle that carbon dioxide can be turned into plant and animal tissue especially wood. As trees grow carbon gets trapped in cellulose and lignin so it's out of the atmosphere for a long time. It's sequestered.

term.name: Carpet Beetle
term.definition: All carpet beetle larvae can feed on wool carpets and other wool products, furs, hides, horns, feathers, hair, and silk; also linen, cotton, and rayon if soiled with juice, food, or animal excreta. They can be pests in cereals, stored grains, nuts, meal, Indian corn, red pepper, etc.; also in insect collections and other museum specimens.

term.name: Carrier
term.definition: An inert liquid or solid used to carry a pesticide to the pest. Examples are solvents in which the pesticide is dissolved, granules on which the pesticide is absorbed, and powders with which the pesticide is mixed.

term.name: Caste
term.definition: A subset of individuals within a colony of social animals (chiefly ants, bees, termites, and wasps) that has a specialized function and is distinguished from other subsets by anatomical differences. Typical insect castes are the queen (the female responsible for reproduction), workers (the usually sterile caretakers of the queen, eggs, and larvae), soldiers (defenders of the colony).

term.name: Category I
term.definition: Highly toxic pesticide: First Aid or Statement of Practical Treatment is required on label.

term.name: Category II
term.definition: Moderately toxic pesticide: First Aid or Statement or Practical Treatment is required on label.

term.name: Category III
term.definition: Slightly toxic pesticide: First Aid or Statement or Practical Treatment not required on front label, but usually placed there.

term.name: Category IV
term.definition: Virtually non-toxic pesticide: First Aid or Statement of Practical Treatment not required, but usually included.

term.name: Caterpillar
term.definition: Larval stage of order Lepidoptera (moths and butterflies).

term.name: Caution
term.definition: Human hazard signal word for pesticides that are slightly toxic to humans. This usually refers to Category III pesticides, although it is legally possible for a Category IV pesticides to bear this signal word

term.name: Cell membrane disrupters
term.definition: Herbicides activated by sunlight, producing oxygen compounds that rupture cells and thus destroy plant tissue. Death of the plant can be very rapid. Paraquat and diquat interfere with electron flow, resulting in free radical formation, which destroys plant membranes and cells

term.name: Cellulose
term.definition: A complex carbohydrate, composed of glucose units, that makes up the cell walls of plants; wood fiber used in paper manufacturing.

term.name: Center for Health Promotion and Preventive Medicine (CHPPM):
term.definition: USA CHPPM provides worldwide technical support for preventive medicine, public health and health promotion and wellness services supporting America's Army in garrison and during deployments.

term.name: Centrifugal pump
term.definition: A machine for moving a liquid, such as water, by accelerating it radially outward in an impeller to a surrounding volute casing.

term.name: Cephalothorax
term.definition: This is a body region consisting of the head and thorax.

term.name: Cerci
term.definition: Tail protrusion; appendages attached to the last abdominal segment of some insects; tactile or touch receptors.

term.name: Certified Pest Controller
term.definition: (Certified Pesticide Applicator) A pesticide applicator who has demonstrated competence (via training and testing) and holds a license to legally apply pesticides, including restricted use pesticides. Applicators may be state and/or DOD certified.

term.name: Certified Pest Management Personnel
term.definition: Any individual who applies pesticides or supervises the use of pesticides, and who has been authorized to do so by successfully completing a training program approved by the EPA, followed by formal certification by the state. Any individual who applies pesticides or supervises the use of pesticides, and who has been authorized to do so by successfully completing a training program approved by the EPA, followed by formal certification by the Personnel from the Department of Defense or one of the states that certify pesticide applicators.

term.name: Chain of Infection
term.definition: A model used to explain the progress of infectious disease which links pathogens, reservoirs, hosts and means of transmission.

term.name: Chelicera
term.definition: (1) One member of the first pair of usually pincer-like appendages of spiders, mites, and other arachnida (2) Paired appendage that arise from the mouth area of arachnidae, in particular scorpions and mites (3) Arthropod jaws; spider chelicerae move in a sciss or-like action; tarantula jaws move in an up and down action.

term.name: Chemical tools (IPM)
term.definition: Use of pesticides, repellants, growth regulators, and other chemicals to manage pest populations

term.name: Chemists
term.definition: Synthesize compounds that have pesticidal activity

term.name: Chemosterilant
term.definition: Pesticide that prevents sexual reproduction of a pest

term.name: Chitin
term.definition: A nitrogenous polysaccharide (sugar and nitrogen) found in arthropod cuticle; gives the cuticle its dark color and strength. (2) A tough semitransparent horny substance; the principal component of the exoskeletons of arthropods and the cell walls of certain fungi.

term.name: Chlorinated hydrocarbon
term.definition: A category of oldies-but-badies, like DDT, Chlordane and Mirex. Oddly, a lot of chlorinated hydrocarbons had limited human toxicity (although Dieldren, Endrin, and Endosulfan were VERY toxic). These pesticides affected the nervous system and caused the injuries you'd expect from nervous system damage. Poisoning victims might experience vomiting, muscular tremors, weakness and numbness, as well as unusual apprehension or excitement. In worst case scenarios, victims lapsed into convulsions and even died. Tragically, this kind of mishap still occurs in rural areas of Africa with long out-of-date pesticides.

term.name: Cholinesterase inhibition
term.definition: Effect of organophosphates and carbamates that causes loss of muscle control, leading to total collapse

term.name: Cholinesterase testing
term.definition: The Army conducts yearly cholinesterase-testing of pesticide applicators because organophosphates and carbamates are such a deadly class of pesticides, attacking the nervous system.

term.name: Choke
term.definition: A valve that controls the flow of air into the carburetor; choking the engine is necessary because gasoline droplets don't evaporate well in a cold engine.

term.name: Choke lever
term.definition: Opens and closes the choke.

term.name: Choriomeningitis
term.definition: A cerebral meningitis with cellular infiltration of the meninges

term.name: Chronic no-effect level
term.definition: A threshold level of exposure to a toxin at which no physiological effect occurs over a 2-year period

term.name: Chronic Toxicity
term.definition: A reaction to a chemical that builds up and becomes apparent over a period of time longer than 24 hours, usually after weeks of exposure

term.name: Cigarette Beetle
term.definition: One of the most common household insect pests in Virginia. It can be found throughout the year, but seems to be more common in the fall and winter months. A serious pantry pest, the range of food makes them difficult to control. There have been larval infestations in dried flower arrangements, causing the flowers to drop or all the petals to fall.

term.name: Class
term.definition: A subdivision of a phylum, containing a group of related orders

term.name: Claws
term.definition: Claws are paired appendages arising from the cephelothorax of a crustacean

term.name: Cleistothecia
term.definition: A closed spherical membrane structure

term.name: Cold Fogging
term.definition: Method of producing ultra-low volume or ultra-low dose aerosols; cold foggers aerosolize pesticides without burning or otherwise subjecting the pesticides to heat. Cold foggers typically force pesticide through incredibly small orifices or spray it onto rapidly spinning disks to atomize the liquid into tiny droplets.

term.name: Coleoptera
term.definition: An order of insects with chewing mouthparts, in which the front pair of wings are more or less hardened and form a sheath for the membraneous second pair.

term.name: Colubrids
term.definition: Any of numerous, widely-distributed, chiefly non-venomous snakes of the family Colubridae, which includes the king snake, garter snakes, and water snakes. The brown treesnake is one of the minority of colubrids that is venomous.

term.name: Commensal
term.definition: Organisms that live with and rely on a host for a benefit but do not harm or benefit the host. For example, small crabs that depend on oyster reefs for refuge are commensal organisms. (In the case of rodents, commensal may not be the most accurate term, since people do suffer harm.) Commensalism with rodents is a one-sided relationship in which rodents get their food and water and shelter from humans, and humans just get to live with rats and mice.

term.name: Commercial applicator
term.definition: An applicator used for commercial use

term.name: Commercial certification
term.definition: A certification authorizing applicators to apply or supervise use of restricted use pesticides for various commercial purposes. DoD pesticide applicators have commercial certification.

term.name: Complete Metamorphosis
term.definition: A process of development in which the immature form looks and acts differently from the adult; the stages of development are egg, larva, pupa, and adult.

term.name: Concentrate
term.definition: Refers to the formulated product before it is diluted by the end user, and consists of a certain percentage of active ingredient, and various inert ingredients (such as, emulsifiers, adjuvants, etc.)

term.name: Concentration
term.definition: The amount of a substance present in a mixture. There are many different ways to express concentration.

term.name: Condemnation Level 1
term.definition: The most stringent of the three condemnation levels; assigned to stored product pests that pose the highest human health hazard; the presence of just one pest condemns the whole lot.

term.name: Condemnation Level 2
term.definition: The presence of 3 insects condemns the product; medical threat, but not as great as level 1.

term.name: Condemnation Level 3
term.definition: The presence of 7 insects condemns the product; product contamination.

term.name: Condemnation Levels
term.definition: The 3 levels of human hazard assigned by the Army and used by veterinarians to assess the safety of product pests; condemnation level 1 means just one insect is enough to condemn the whole lot; for level 2--the presence of 3 insects condemns one pound of product; for level 3--the presence of 7 insects condemns one pound of product.

term.name: Confused Flour Beetle
term.definition: A Tribolium flour beetle; very common pest infesting flour mills, warehouses, and grocery stores; they also feed on grain, beans, dried fruits, nuts, chocolate, and other foods in the house; the most abundant and injurious insect pest of flour mills in the United States. The red and confused flour beetles live in the same environment and compete for resources.

term.name: Conifers
term.definition: Any of various mostly needle-leaved or scale-leaved, chiefly evergreen, cone-bearing gymnospermous trees or shrubs such as pines, spruces, and firs.

term.name: Conjunctiva
term.definition: The mucous membrane that lines the inner surface of the eyelids.

term.name: Conspicuous
term.definition: Easily seen or noticed; readily observable. (Directions for Use must be conspicuously placed on the label.)

term.name: Constant flow valve
term.definition: Regulates spray pressure at a certain level. If the valve is designed to operate at 21 pounds per square inch, spray pressure will remain at that level until tank pressure drops below 21 psi. At that point the valve closes and the flow shuts off.

term.name: Contact Foliage Applied Herbicide
term.definition: A chemical that kills primarily by contact with plant tissue, with little or no translocation.

term.name: Control handle
term.definition: Allows operator to control the sprayer without taking it off his or her shoulders.

term.name: Conversion, pounds to kilograms
term.definition: To do the lethal dose calculation, first convert pounds to kilograms using the formula: weight in pounds X 2.2.

term.name: Cornicles
term.definition: Abdominal spikes

term.name: Core Phase
term.definition: That part of an applicator certification course addressing subjects common to all pest management, such as laws and regulations, pesticide safety, label reading and so on. A student must successfully complete the core phase to gain any kind of certification.

term.name: Corvids
term.definition: A family of songbirds which includes crows, ravens, magpies and jays.

term.name: Cost-Conscious Pest Control
term.definition: Originated by farmers concerned about the bottom-line. Example: It will cost you $1,000 for judicious use of some pesticide in conjunction with other control measures. Left untreated you can expect $1,999 in pest damages. By spending $1,000 you save $999 in damages. This is a good deal for your pocketbook and a good deal for the environment.

term.name: Coxal glands
term.definition: In certain arthropods, a pair of excretory organs consisting of an end sac where initial urine is collected, a tubule where secretion and re-absorption may take place, and an excretory pore at the base (coxa) of one of the legs.

term.name: Crustacean
term.definition: Any of various predominantly aquatic arthropods of the class Crustacea, including lobsters, crabs, shrimps, and barnacles, characteristically having a segmented body, a chitinous exoskeleton, and paired jointed limbs.

term.name: Cubed
term.definition: Multiplying a number by itself 3 times, or raising a number to the third power e.g. 3Â³.

term.name: Culex
term.definition: A mosquito genus.

term.name: Cultural tools (IPM)
term.definition: Non-chemical alteration of the environment (sanitation, draining surface waters, removing pest habitat).

term.name: Curative Pesticide
term.definition: A chemical used to kill or inhibit existing pest infestations. This type of pesticide is commonly used to control existing fungal infestations.

term.name: Customer Education
term.definition: Arguably the most important step in IPM; teaching the customer about good facilities management, to include, structural repairs, maintenance, and sanitation. Proper maintenance and housekeeping will prevent pest problems from occurring in the first place.

term.name: Cutaneous
term.definition: Affecting or existing on the skin surface; as in cutaneous leishmaniasis.

term.name: Cutaneous Leishmaniasis
term.definition: A form of leishmaniasis that causes lesions on the skin surface.

term.name: Cuticle
term.definition: Epidermis, outer skin of insect. The non-cellular outer wall of the arthropod exoskeleton, composed of chitin.

term.name: D.
term.definition: Dust. As in Turflon D

term.name: Danger
term.definition: Human hazard signal word for Category I pesticides that are very toxic to humans by virtue of local eye and skin effects only.

term.name: Danger - Poison
term.definition: Human hazard signal word for Category I pesticides that are very toxic to humans by oral, dermal, or inhalation exposure.

term.name: DD Form 1532
term.definition: The 1532-1 is a record, but NOT a report. Installations REPORT pest management activities for the entire installation on the DD Form 1532, its electronic equivalent. Using the daily records of pest management activities, the 1532 tells the command all about pest management on a given installation. On the 1532, all the pesticide usage traceable in terms of pounds of active ingredient, as well as other control activities like surveillance and trapping are reported. Every organization that applies pesticides MUST report that usage to the pest management coordinator. In the past, everyone submitted the 1532 once a month, but now, different commands may require reporting once a quarter, or even once a year.

term.name: DD Form 1532-1
term.definition: The DD Form 1532-1 is the ONLY military form that records pest management BY FACILITY! Remember, a facility can be a building, parade ground, ball field, or a road side ditch. It's where the pesticide is applied and allows someone to identify the place of repeated applications of pesticide. A lot of military installations around the country are being closed, and the DD Form 1532-1 is used to help with pre-closure environmental condition surveys. It's good to know where DDT or chlordane or other persistent pesticides have gone.

term.name: Dead-End Host
term.definition: Disease recipient that dies or recovers without passing on the disease.

term.name: Dengue fever
term.definition: A viral disease vectored by mosquitoes; also known as break bone fever.

term.name: Deregistered pesticides
term.definition: Pesticides for which the EPA hs removed registration due to safety/environmental issues or at the manufacturer's request.

term.name: Dermal (and oral) toxins
term.definition: Toxins absorbed through the skin (or ingested through the mouth). Measured using LD50 values.

term.name: Dermal absorption
term.definition: Occurs when a toxin is allowed to contact and penetrate skin. Any pesticide containing oil or solvents can be absorbed through unprotected human skin. A pesticide applicator applies pesticide, then uses the rest room without first washing his hands.

term.name: Dermestid Beetles
term.definition: Beetles belonging to the family Dermestidae, such as: larder, carpenter, furniture carpenter and khapra beetles.

term.name: Desiccating pesticide
term.definition: Pesticide that kills the target pest by mechanical means. Specifically, it abrades (rubs off) the waxy coating on the cuticle (outer skin) of insect causing it to dehydrate and die, e.g., dust like silica aerogel or diatomaceous earth. Desiccants work slowly. Thus they wouldn't be appropriate on a pest that stings, such as a yellow jacket wasp.

term.name: Desiccation
term.definition: (1) Dryness resulting from the removal of water (2) To make or become completely dry

term.name: Deuterocerebrum
term.definition: The middle section of the insect brain, formed by the ganglia (nerve center) of the second primary segment. The arthropod "brain" is actually a collection of ganglia compressed into a single organ made up of the: protocerebrum, deuterocerebrum, and tritocerebrum.

term.name: Diameter
term.definition: The length of a straight line passing through the center of a circle and connecting two points on the circumference.

term.name: Diapause
term.definition: (1) Extended rest period of quiescence between periods of growth or reproductive activity (e.g., hibernation in winter, estivation in summer) (2) Period of rest when insects are inactive due to temperature extremes; hibernation in winter, estivation in summer.

term.name: Diaphragm pump
term.definition: A positive displacement pump that uses a combination of the reciprocating action of a rubber or Teflon diaphragm and suitable non-return check valves to pump a fluid.

term.name: Dictyoptera
term.definition: Includes three groups of insects, the Isoptera (termites), Blattodea (or Blattaria; cockroaches) and the Mantodea (mantids, or praying mantises). The use of the term Dictyoptera has changed over the years, and while largely out of use for much of the last century, it is becoming more widely used. It is presently usually considered a superorder, with Isoptera, Blattodea and Mantodea being its three orders. In some classifications, however, Dictyoptera is shifted to order status. Regardless, in all classifications, the three constituent groups are the same, just treated at different rank. Termites and roaches are very closely related, and together are the sister group to the mantids.

term.name: Diffusion
term.definition: Process by which liquids spread through a matrix. Water-borne wood preservatives, like the borates, diffuse through a piece of wood under moist conditions.

term.name: Diluent
term.definition: (1) A substance used to reduce the percentage of active ingredient of a pesticide. This might be, for example, the water added by a pesticide applicator, or the food bait added by a manufacturer to attract rodents and mask rodenticide. (2) Food bait used to attract the rodent and mask the rodenticide.

term.name: Dilution effect
term.definition: The larger the space, the larger the dilution effect. Thus, it is always safer to apply pesticides outdoors where dilution is greatest.

term.name: Dioxin
term.definition: Toxic contaminant deregistered (banned) in 1984.

term.name: Direct relationship
term.definition: Relationship between two variables a and b in which an increase in a results in the same increase in variable b. There is a direct relationship between nozzle size and flow rate. As the nozzle size increases, the flow rate increases.

term.name: Discharge rate
term.definition: Synonym for flow rate of pesticide.

term.name: Disease Triad
term.definition: The 3 elements (vector, pathogen and host) that make vector borne disease transmission possible.

term.name: Disease Vectors
term.definition: Pests which carry disease, e.g., the Anopheles mosquito vectors malaria; body lice vector typhus.

term.name: Displacement pump
term.definition: Any pump with a pulsing action, produced by compressed air, steam or a plunger.

term.name: Dispersing agent
term.definition: An adjuvant that facilitates mixing and suspension of a pesticide formulation in water.

term.name: Distal
term.definition: Near or towards the free end of an appendage. The part of a segment or appendage that is furthest away from the center of the body.

term.name: Disturbed Soil
term.definition: Any soil that has been dug up or ploughed. (Argentine ants colonize disturbed soil.)

term.name: Dorsal
term.definition: Pertaining to the back.

term.name: Drift
term.definition: (1) Movement of an herbicide away from the target plant and into the atmosphere; caused by rain or wind. (2) The physical movement of pesticide droplets or particles through the air at the time of pesticide application or soon thereafter from the target site to any non or off-target site. Drift can expose people, wildlife, and the environment to pesticide residues that can cause health and environmental effects and property damage. Example: honeybees that are killed far from the actual pesticide application site.

term.name: DRMO
term.definition: Defense Reutilization and Marketing Office handles recycling and sale/disposal of obsolete military supplies and equipment. It is responsible for disposing of unwanted but still packaged and labeled pesticides.

term.name: Drugstore Beetle
term.definition: Attacks such a wide variety of foods and material; Eats anything but cast iron. It gets its name from its habit of feeding on prescription drugs. It also feeds on flours, dry mixes, breads, cookies, chocolates and other sweets, and spices. Non-food material includes wool, hair, leather, horn, and museum specimens. It is found in pigeon nests and is known to bore into books, wooden objects, and in some cases, tin or aluminum foil and lead sheets. Larval feeding accounts for the greatest amount of damage. Museum and herbarium specimens are vulnerable to attack.

term.name: Dry boom
term.definition: a type of boom that does not carry liquid. The boom serves as support for nozzles which are supplied by spray tubing.

term.name: Dry flowable
term.definition: A dry, granular pesticide formulation that forms a suspension when added to water. Same as Water Dispersible Granule.

term.name: Dust
term.definition: A finely ground, dry pesticide formulation containing a small amount of active ingredient and a large amount of inert carrier or diluent such as clay or talc.

term.name: E or EC
term.definition: Emulsifiable concentrate. As in Prograss EC.

term.name: Ecdysis
term.definition: Molting; the process of shedding the exoskeleton.

term.name: Economic Threshold
term.definition: Point at which spending money on pest control becomes cheaper than the continued costs of pest damage. During a public health crisis, however, (mosquitoes and West Nile virus, ticks and Lyme disease, or fleas and Bubonic plague) cost is not factored into the equation

term.name: Ecosystem
term.definition: Stable and self-sustaining system formed by the interaction of a community of organisms with their environment; a living community.

term.name: Ectoparasites
term.definition: (1) Fleas, lice, ticks, etc.; organisms that grow, feed, and are sheltered on the outside of another animal while contributing nothing to the survival of its host. (2) Pests such as fleas and lice that feed on living animals from outside, usually by taking blood meals. (3) A parasite, such as the flea, that lives on the outer surface of its host.

term.name: Elapidae
term.definition: A family of poisonous reptiles, including cobras, kraits, mambas, and coral snakes; all have a pteroglyph fang arrangement (fixed front fangs).

term.name: Elephantiasis
term.definition: Later complication of Filariasis; swollen lymph nodes and relapses lead to vastly enlarged and deformed extremities.

term.name: Emergence holes
term.definition: The holes gnawed out by adult wood-feeding beetles as they leave larval tunnels and emerge into the outer world.

term.name: Emergent
term.definition: Arising from a liquid or other medium. An aquatic plant having its stem leaves, etc., extending above the surface of the water.

term.name: Emergent (Secondary) Pest
term.definition: Pest species that becomes a problem for the ecosystem only after a stronger competitor for the same food source has been removed Pests A and B normally compete for the same food within a given ecosystem. When Pest A is eliminated as a result of a pesticide application, pest B emerges as the new problem and has a field day, aggressively monopolizing the food source. Pest B is now the emergent or secondary pest. Example: Plant mites attack crops after aphid control.

term.name: Emulsifiable concentrate
term.definition: A pesticide formulation produced by mixing an active ingredient and an emulsifying agent in a suitable petroleum solvent. When added to water, a milky emulsion is formed.

term.name: Emulsifier
term.definition: A substance that stabilizes a suspension of droplets of one liquid in another liquid which otherwise would not mix. Commonly used to facilitate the mixing of an oil in water.

term.name: Emulsion
term.definition: A mixture in which one liquid is suspended as small droplets in another liquid.

term.name: Encapsulated pesticide
term.definition: A pesticide formulation with the active ingredient enclosed in capsules of polyvinyl or other synthetic materials. Used primarily for slow release.

term.name: Encephalitis
term.definition: A viral disease vectored by mosquitoes and ticks, causing inflammation of the brain and spinal column.

term.name: Endemic
term.definition: Native to a particular nation, area, or region.

term.name: Endoparasite
term.definition: A parasite, such as a tapeworm, that lives within another organism

term.name: Endophily
term.definition: The urge to enter human dwellings shown by domestic or filth flies, as well as other animals.

term.name: End tag
term.definition: Label found at the end of a piece of treated wood. It indicates type and amount of preservative used.

term.name: Enteric
term.definition: Pertaining to the intestines.

term.name: Enteric Bacteria
term.definition: Bacterial pathogens that transmit intestinal diseases, such as: shigella, typhoid, cholera, salmonellosis, poliomyelitis, tuberculosis, and leprosy.

term.name: Entomologists
term.definition: Provide biological and taxonomic information about insects and related arthropods. Evaluate efficacy of pesticides such as insecticides and miticides.

term.name: Environmental Hazard
term.definition: The product is potentially harmful to wildlife, fish, endangered animals and plants, or may adversely impact wetlands or water resources.

term.name: Environmental Performance Assessment Survey (EPAS)
term.definition: The EPAS program assists all Army commanders in attaining, sustaining, and monitoring compliance with Federal, State, and local environmental laws and regulations, as well as DoD and Army compliance and performance requirements. EPAS external and internal multi-media assessments: - Identify non-compliance with environmental regulations and non-conformance with the ISO 14001 environmental performance standard used by Army EMS; - Provide suggestions for both immediate and long-term corrective actions; and - Indicate resources needed for implementation.

term.name: Environmental safety in IPM
term.definition: an ecosystem-based strategy that attempts to minimize risks to human health, beneficial organisms, and the environment by targeting only target pests, using the least-invasive methods that can do the job, and conforming to restrictions on endangered species.

term.name: Enzyme
term.definition: A protein molecule that catalyzes (increases the velocity of) chemical reactions of other substances without itself being destroyed or altered upon completion of the reaction.

term.name: EPA
term.definition: Environmental Protection Agency. The Federal agency responsible for promulgating and implementing environmental regulations.

term.name: EPA registration number
term.definition: Number unique to each chemical; completely identifies the pesticide; the one number that identifies the pesticide like a fingerprint. Using just this number, you can look up all available information on this chemical from the EPA database.

term.name: Epidemiology
term.definition: The study of epidemics and epidemic diseases.

term.name: Epithelium
term.definition: (1) A tissue composed of epithelial cells. Such tissue, like the lining of the intestines, tends to surround parts of the body, somewhat like a cell membrane. It is also used to form glands. (2) Thin layer of tissue that covers organs, glands, and other structures within the body. The pathogen, Ricketsia ricketsii, that causes Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever, multiplies in the epithelium of blood vessels.

term.name: Epizootic
term.definition: An epidemic of an animal disease, e.g, bluetongue disease in sheep.

term.name: Establishment Number
term.definition: This number identifies the final facility where the pesticide was manufactured.

term.name: Estivation
term.definition: Period of dormancy during the summer, during periods of high temperatures or dry periods. Seen in mosquitoes that are active in the winter/spring but not in the heat of the summer.

term.name: Even spray flat fan nozzle
term.definition: type of nozzle used for row-crop treatment. Nozzles aren't overlapped. Each nozzle produces an even flow all the way across the spray pattern, so that the same ounces per minute is generated from the center and edges of the pattern.

term.name: Exit holes
term.definition: See ""Emergence holes.

term.name: Exo-Skeletal Insect
term.definition: Insect with hardened external support structure, such as crustaceans, turtles, and fish. Arthropods have an outside shell. The exoskeleton of a fly or moth is thin and weak. That of a crab or lobster is thick and strong.

term.name: Exoskeleton
term.definition: A skeleton or supporting structure that is outside the body

term.name: Extirpated Species
term.definition: Species that have become locally extinct since the introduction of European settlements; for example: in Guam, many native species of birds have been extirpated by the browntree snake.

term.name: Extrapolation
term.definition: Calculation of unknown values from known values. For example, if Jimmy makes $100 a day, we can extrapolate to say that he'll make $1,000 in 10 days.

term.name: F or FL
term.definition: Flowable. As in Guthion 3F

term.name: Facilities Management
term.definition: (Better known as Directorate of Public Works on most installations); fixing building issues that would cause a structure to be favorable for pests. Pests are looking for food, water and shelter. Any measure that prevents their access to these three things will help to lower the ir numbers. Thus, DPW would fix a broken screen door that would allow flies access to a kitchen.

term.name: Facility
term.definition: For pesticide recording purposes, a facility can be a building, parade ground, ball field, or a road side ditch. It's where the pesticide is applied and allows someone to identify the place of repeated applications of pesticide.

term.name: Facultative Parasites
term.definition: Parasites, such as fungi, that can survive either by parasitizing a host, or by some other means, such as living off decaying matter

term.name: Family
term.definition: A subdivision of an order, usually ending with the suffix, -idea

term.name: Fan unit
term.definition: Provides the air blast that disperses pesticide; actually sprays out liquid pesticide in mist-sized droplets.

term.name: Federal stock code
term.definition: Series 6840 is assigned to all pesticides, herbicides, fungicides and rodenticides.

term.name: Fuel line
term.definition: Moves fuel from the tank to the engine.

term.name: Filarial Worm
term.definition: Several species of small, thread-like parasitic nematode worms known to infect humans, some of them containing the causative agents of river blindness (Onchocerca) and elephantiasis (Brugia, Wuchereria).

term.name: Filth Flies
term.definition: Flies that live on garbage (house flies, blow flies and flesh flies, and soldier flies*). They pick up pathogenic organisms from sewage, garbage, manure, decaying bodies and other such sources. These flying pests initially pick up dangerous organisms with their mouth and other body parts. The organisms are then passed on to humans and animals through the feces and vomit of the fly.

term.name: Finished spray
term.definition: Refers to a pesticide mixture with all concentrate, diluent, adjuvants and other materials added, and ready to apply

term.name: Fix
term.definition: Make biologically available; as in bacteria in the gut of the termite that make nitrogen biologically available to termites so that they can obtain proteins.

term.name: Flagellated
term.definition: Having whip-like appendages

term.name: Flash Point
term.definition: The lowest temperature at which a liquid will give off sufficient vapor to ignite on application of a flame.

term.name: Flashback
term.definition: Hazard that may be present near valves on pressurized pesticide cans. In the event of fire, a flashback prevention valve keeps flame from getting back into the container and causing an even bigger problem (an explosion in your hand, for example). It's analogous to backflow prevention valves in plumbing systems.

term.name: Flat fan nozzle
term.definition: type of nozzle used on most boom sprayers (except for row crop application). Each spray pattern produces more flow at the center of the nozzle than on the sides, so the patterns can be overlapped to produce even flow across the boom.

term.name: Flow Rate
term.definition: A measurement used for pesticide spray nozzles. In the United States, nozzles are rated according to the gallons of spray per minute (gpm) they will produce at a certain pressure, measured in pounds per square inch, or psi.

term.name: Flowable
term.definition: A pesticide formulation in which a very finely ground solid particle is suspended (not dissolved) in a liquid carrier.

term.name: Foliar application
term.definition: Application of pesticides to plant foliage (the leaves of the plant).

term.name: Foraging
term.definition: The seeking and obtaining of food.

term.name: Formulation
term.definition: (1) The mixture of active and other ingredients in a pesticide that affects the active ingredient's solubility. (2) The form in which a pesticide is prepared for practical use (usually this is the product purchased by the pest manager). Also, the term for the manufacturing process of making a formulation. (3) The manner in which a pesticide's active ingredient is made for practical use.

term.name: Frass
term.definition: Debris or excrement produced by insects.

term.name: Fraud
term.definition: Deception, trickery, or breach of contract. Misrepresentation of a product, as to its use, safety, etc.

term.name: Fruiting body
term.definition: A fungal structure used to produce and disseminate spores: a spore-producing structure.

term.name: Full-cell process
term.definition: Also known as the Bethel process; a pressure and vacuum system designed to put the maximum preservative into wood.

term.name: Fumigant
term.definition: (1) Small organic molecules that are gases above 40 degrees Fahrenheit. They are heavier than air and are highly penetrating, but non-persistent. Fumigants are highly toxic. (2) A pesticide that forms gases that are toxic to plants, animals, and microorganisms. (3) PLURAL: Pesticides that actually become a gas after release and infiltrate an enclosed space.

term.name: Fungicides
term.definition: Pesticides that kill fungi.

term.name: Fungus
term.definition: Any of various organisms such as molds, mildew, mushrooms etc. that lack chlorophyll, stems and leaves and reproduce by spores.

term.name: Furniture Carpet Beetle
term.definition: As its name suggests, the furniture carpet beetle is most commonly found feeding at carpet edges, under baseboards, and in upholstered furniture.

term.name: G.
term.definition: As in Merit O.5G. G stands for granular.

term.name: Galleries
term.definition: System of tunnels or nests in wood that are gnawed out by insects such as termites, carpenter ants and beetles.

term.name: Galls
term.definition: Abnormal growths of plant tissues caused by various parasites, fungi, bacteria, insects, and mites.

term.name: Galvanic corrosion
term.definition: An electrochemical action which takes place when dissimilar metals are in contact in the presence of an electrolyte, resulting in corrosion.

term.name: Galvanized
term.definition: Dipped in zinc. Steel sheets are dipped into molten zinc. Termite shields can be made of galvanized metal as an alternative to the costly copper termite shields.

term.name: Ganglia
term.definition: A gray mass of nerve tissues

term.name: Genus
term.definition: A subdivision of a family, the first name in the binomial nomenclature (genus + species) of an organism.

term.name: Gestation
term.definition: Period of time between fertilization and birth of an animal. Commonly called pregnancy in humans.

term.name: GOCO
term.definition: Acronym for Government-Owned, Contractor-Operated. Examples of GOCO facilities include: ammunition storage facilities and Army Family Housing.

term.name: GPM
term.definition: Gallons per minute

term.name: Granary Weevils
term.definition: Both granary and rice weevils, often known as "Snout weevils", penetrate and feed on the internal portions of whole grains during the larval (immature) stage, making early detection of infestations difficult. Usually found in grain storage or processing plants, infesting wheat, oats, rye, barley, rice, and corn. Although not often found in the home, sometimes they infest table beans, acorns, chestnuts, birdseed, sunflower seeds, and ornamental corn. Rarely found in macaroni and spaghetti.

term.name: Green glands
term.definition: A pair of excretory organs in each side of the head region of certain crustaceans, emptying at the base of the antennae.

term.name: Gribbles
term.definition: A very destructive crustacean that colonizes wood in marine environments. Gribbles generally colonize marine pilings and can degrade wood to the point that it's completely destroyed. Gribbles, like shipworms (or teredos) are also referred to as "marine borers" for their wood destroying habits.

term.name: Grip
term.definition: Link between the operator's hand and the starter rope.

term.name: Grooming
term.definition: Social behavior whereby termites clean each other, typically removing excess dirt and fungal spores; this is important in the control of pathogens. Where an individual being groomed is deemed to be damaged or unfit, grooming may lead to cannibalism.

term.name: Ground Water
term.definition: Water that is deep under the surface of the earth, as in wells and springs.

term.name: Growth Regulators
term.definition: Pesticides that stimulate or retard the growth of pests by disrupting their normal life cycle.

term.name: Guano
term.definition: A substance composed chiefly of the dung of sea birds or bats; accumulated along certain coastal areas and caves and used as fertilizer.

term.name: Habitat
term.definition: The natural abode or locality of an animal, plant, etc.

term.name: Habitat loss
term.definition: The destruction of habitats required by wildlife for survival resulting from human population growth and the consumption of open space and resources.

term.name: Habitat Manipulation
term.definition: Removing or altering a pest habitat (place where pests live and feed) by making it inhospitable; habitat manipulation is an IPM control measure that falls under the category of facilities management.

term.name: Half-life
term.definition: The time required for the potency of a chemical to fall to half of its potency or to be eliminated from the body. For example, if the potency is 32 with a half-life of 15 years, the potency will be 16 in 15 years and then will drop by half each of the following 15 years to 16, then 8, then 6, etc.

term.name: Harborage
term.definition: (1) A place of refuge. For pests, the place where they find shelter and food. (2) A place of refuge, where animals, such as rodents find shelter. (3) Place or shelter where pests live. (Removing the harborage may eliminate the pest; facilities management). Structural repairs, such as caulking and sealing will remove the harborage of cockroaches, ants, and silverfish.

term.name: Heartwood
term.definition: The wood from the central trunk of a mature tree -- containing natural preservative chemicals; modern forestry techniques produces lumber that's all sapwood-very edible for termites.

term.name: Heartworms
term.definition: Micro filarial worms vectored by mosquitoes: these worms cause heartworm disease in dogs.

term.name: Hemi-Hydrobionts
term.definition: A group of animals that lives only partially in water, such as horsefly larva, which live in muddy soil.

term.name: Hemicellulose
term.definition: A carbohydrate which in addition to cellulose and lignin is one of the most important components of timber.

term.name: Hemolymph
term.definition: The blood of lower invertebrates. (You do need to know that arachnids, terrestrial or land living arthropods breathe either through spiracles or book lungs. The spiracles are on the body surface, and take air to individual cells. The book lungs are a stack of thin exoskeleton. An arachnid's hemolymph, or circulatory fluid, travels through the book lungs, becomes oxygenated, and then travels throughout its body.)

term.name: Hemotoxic
term.definition: Causing breakdown of the circulatory system. (The venom of the viper is hemotoxic as well as neurotoxic and digests protein, causing tissue damage.)

term.name: Herbicides
term.definition: Pesticide that kill plants

term.name: Hermaphrodite
term.definition: An arthropod, such as an earthworm (phyla Annelida) or plant, having both male and female reproductive organs.

term.name: Hibernation
term.definition: A period of lethargy or suspended animation in animals occurring during seasonal low temperatures.

term.name: Histoplasmosis
term.definition: Respiratory infection caused by fungi that grow in the acid dust under bird or bat droppings.

term.name: Honeydew
term.definition: Sticky, sugary secretion deposited on plants by insects such as aphid and whitefly and collected by ants.

term.name: Horizontal barrier
term.definition: Termiticide applied to graded soil or gravel fill under foundation.

term.name: Hormone
term.definition: A product of living cells that circulates in animal or plant fluids and that produces a specific effect on cell activity remote from its point of origin.

term.name: Horticultural oils
term.definition: Light petroleum oil mixed with emulsifier. These oils are mixed with water and sprayed over scales and other arthropod species to reduce oxygen intake and kill.

term.name: Host
term.definition: An organism capable of contracting a disease.

term.name: Host Specific
term.definition: (1) An organism that depends upon one particular species of plants, animal, or insect for its food or habitat. For example, the pubic louse lives only on human beings, and only in the pubic hair of its human host. Now THAT'S specific! (2) The characteristic of pests feeding only on one host, even if they starve to death; a form of bio-control is to introduce a new, host-specific species, such as parasitic wasps into a habitat to lay eggs only on a problem pest.

term.name: Human Hazard Signal Words
term.definition: Required on the front panel of the label, these words describe a hierarchy of pesticide toxicity to humans. From least to most toxic, they are: 1. Caution (Slightly toxic), 2. Warning (Moderately toxic), 3. Danger (Highly toxic eye effects), 4. Danger-Poison (Highly toxic - dermal, oral, inhalation). The human hazard level is indicated in Area 7 of the label: human hazard signal words

term.name: Hydramethylnon
term.definition: The active ingredient in AMDRO; a slow-acting stomach poison that prevents the insect from making ATP (Energy).

term.name: Hydrobionts
term.definition: A group of animals that lives mostly in water, such as deerfly larva.

term.name: Hydrocele
term.definition: Later complication of Filariasis; accumulation of serous fluid in the testes.

term.name: Hydrophidae
term.definition: Any of numerous venomous aquatic viviparous snakes having a fin-like tail; of warm coastal seas; feed on fish which they immobilize with quick-acting venom

term.name: Hydrostatic pressure
term.definition: The pressure exerted by a fluid at equilibrium at a given point within the fluid, due to the force of gravity

term.name: Hymenoptera
term.definition: An order of insects with membranous wings and chewing mouthparts, including: bees; wasps; ants; ichneumons; sawflies; gall wasps and so on.

term.name: Hymenopterans
term.definition: Insects belonging to the order hymenoptera and having membranous wings; a wasp is a hymenoptera (singular), wasps, bees, and ants are all hymenoptera (plural); many hymenopterans are venomous insects (though, not all ants are veno" mous)

term.name: Hypercalcemia
term.definition: Leaching of calcium from the bones into the bloodstream, producing elevated blood calcium levels. The anti-coagulant rodenticide, Cholecalciferol (Vitamin D3) causes death by hypercalcemia, leading to cardiac arrest, by leaching calcium from the rodent's bones into it's bloodstream.

term.name: Hyperparsitism
term.definition: A condition in which a secondary parasite develops within a previously existing parasite.

term.name: Hypha
term.definition: (plural, hyphae) One of the filament-like threads that makes up the body of a fungus. Any of the threadlike filaments forming the mycelium of a fungus.

term.name: Hypopus
term.definition: Diapause or dormant phase of mite nymphs; during this phase mites are resistant to almost any control technique.

term.name: Identifying Information
term.definition: For each pesticide, there are nearly a half-dozen pieces of identifying information that must be entered: trade name, formulation, NSN, EPA no., unit of issue, unit of measurement, total amount received, amount on hand, active ingredient, conversion factor. (All of these can be found on the label except for the NSN, total received, amount on hand, and the conversion factor.)

term.name: IGR
term.definition: Insect growth regulator. As in Gentrol IGR Concentrate. IGRs prevent maturation of insects, and in some cases disrupt chitin (a component of the exoskeleton) synthesis.

term.name: Illegal Application
term.definition: Any application contrary to the label directions.

term.name: Imadacloprid
term.definition: The active ingredient (a.i) in MERIT; mimics the action of nicotine in the insect; nerve poison.

term.name: Immediately dangerous to life and health
term.definition: The maximum level of a contaminant (usually measured in parts per million) to which a healthy individual can be exposed for 30 minutes and escape without suffering irreversible health effects or impairing" symptoms. For example, you might be able to work for 30 minutes in an atmosphere containing 2 parts per million of chemical X, whereas at 3 ppm you'd immediately collapse.

term.name: Impeller
term.definition: any person or thing that impels, as the rotor-like part in a water pump.

term.name: Inactive Ingredients
term.definition: Other ingredients besides the active ingredient, that affect solubility (ability to stick) and other functions. Also known as adjuvants.

term.name: Incidental Host
term.definition: (See Amplifying Host).

term.name: Incising
term.definition: A process by which uniform cuts are made in the wood to improve the penetration of wood preservatives.

term.name: Indian Meal Moth
term.definition: A minor to significant pantry pest of stored dried food materials. Infestations can be persistent, requiring cleanliness and exclusion practices such as hermetically sealed containers for food.

term.name: Inert Ingredients
term.definition: Substances in a pesticide that are not the actual active (toxic) ingredient. They may include solvents, diluents, synergists, and other additives. The percentage (but not usually the chemical name or composition) must be listed" as part of the statement of ingredients. Also see inactive ingredients.

term.name: Inguinal
term.definition: Pertaining to the area of the groin.

term.name: Inhalation Absorption
term.definition: The most dangerous form of exposure (as compared to dermal and oral absorption) because the lungs absorb almost 100 percent of the toxin within 30 minutes.

term.name: Inhaled toxins
term.definition: Toxic vapors, fumigants, or finely-ground dusts, that are taken inhaled, especially when applied indoors. This happens to pesticide applicators who fail to use a respirator when needed. They are measured using LC50 values.

term.name: Initial assessment
term.definition: series of five questions that you should ask in order to size up the situation and determine if there is, in fact, a pest management problem that warrants developing an IPM strategy.

term.name: Inorganic Compounds
term.definition: The oldest group of rodenticides; these contain no carbon. They were too lethal for humans, and animals, and they were persistent (they never broke down), remaining in the atmosphere for years. One exception is white phosphorus, but it too is a highly toxic, restricted use, category I rodenticide. It must be mixed underwater.

term.name: Inorganic Insecticides
term.definition: Contain no carbon at all.

term.name: Inorganic Pesticides
term.definition: (Made from metals, they don't contain carbon.) Lead arsenate, a form of arsenic is still used; but this category has been largely replaced by the synthetic insecticides. Exposure causes vomiting, bloody diarrhea, headache, dizziness, cramps, and destruction of the intestinal lining, if swallowed.

term.name: Insect Growth Regulators
term.definition: Pesticides that stimulate or retard the growth of pests by disrupting their normal life cycle.

term.name: Insect Order Dictyoptera
term.definition: See Dictyoptera.

term.name: Insecticidal Soap
term.definition: Soap that coats the spiracles (air/water passages), blocking the flow of air and causing quick suffocation.

term.name: Insecticides
term.definition: Pesticides that kill insects.

term.name: Installation Medical Authority (IMA)
term.definition: IMA is at the center of the Army's initiative to mold installation support functions into a corporate structure, enabling equitable, efficient and effective management of Army installations worldwide. The IMA supports readiness, promotes well-being of soldiers, civilians and family members, and preserves infrastructure and the environment.

term.name: Instar
term.definition: Molting stage of young immature insect: 1st instar, 2nd instar, 3rd instar, 4th instar.

term.name: Integrated Pest Management (IPM) (1)
term.definition: This is a multi-faceted approach for managing pests by combining biological, cultural, physical, and chemical tools in a way that minimizes economic, health, and environmental risks. IPM stresses low toxicity and the use of non-pesticides when possible.

term.name: Integrated Pest Management (IPM) (2)
term.definition: A comprehensive plan for preventing or controlling a pest problem, based on the total situation; the why of the pest problem. (IPM may include a combination of possible controls: facilities management, mechanical, physical, biological, regulatory, and chemical controls, as appropriate to the situation.)

term.name: Intertidal areas below the mean high water mark
term.definition: An area between the extremes of high and low tides which is rather low and may retain water or may dry out. If a pesticide is applied here the water will be contaminated during high tides

term.name: Intracellular Parasites
term.definition: Pathogens such as those of the genus-species, rickettsia spp; like viruses, they cannot live outside a living cell

term.name: Invader Species
term.definition: One of several stored product pests, such as the flour beetle, that enters packages through openings

term.name: Inverse relationship
term.definition: In mathematics, an inverse relationship means that as one variable (like velocity) gets larger, another variable (like amount of pesticide applied) gets proportionally smaller, such that the product of the two variables remains the same.

term.name: Invertebrates
term.definition: Animals with no backbone. In the kingdom Animalia animals belonging to these phyla are invertebrates: Annelida (e.g., segmented worms), Mollusca (e.g., clams), Arthropoda (e.g., insects).

term.name: IPM
term.definition: Integrated Pest Management. A strategy of reducing pests by using a variety of suitable techniques that may include chemical and non-chemical methods.

term.name: IPMIS
term.definition: Integrated Pest Management Information System.

term.name: Jacobson's Organ
term.definition: Sensory apparatus on the roof of a snake's mouth. The snake collects chemicals from the environment and brings them to the Jacobson's organ. Using its forked tongue a snake can sense many things from the environment, such as the presence of prey species, or the location of a potential mate during mating season.

term.name: Juvenile hormones
term.definition: Synthetic growth hormones that disrupt insect life cycles by preventing maturation.

term.name: Khapra Beetle
term.definition: A beetle accidentally introduced to several places in the United States that is an extremely destructive grain pest. "Khapra" means destroyer in Sanskrit.

term.name: King
term.definition: The king and queen are primary reproductives that have managed to mate and begin a colony. (Alates who make it good.)

term.name: Kingdom
term.definition: This is the highest order of biological classification based on life forms that share fundamental similarities.

term.name: L
term.definition: Liquid, a pesticide formulation that is already in a liquid form

term.name: Lambda-Cyhalothrin
term.definition: The active ingredient (a.i) in DEMAND Pest Tab; a pyrethroid nerve poison.

term.name: Larder Beetle
term.definition: Named for the larder, the pantry or cellar where food is stored; often found in houses--and not just in the larder (the kitchen); they eat food in the kitchen or pantry.

term.name: Larva
term.definition: The immature stage (between egg and pupa) of an insect having complete metamorphosis. A butterfly is an insect with complete metamorphosis.

term.name: Lateral
term.definition: Pertaining to the side, either the left or right side.

term.name: Lateral Movement
term.definition: Movement of herbicide across sloping ground after rain into non-target areas.

term.name: LC50
term.definition: Known as a toxicity value. The lethal concentration of chemical in the air inhaled by land animals or absorbed through the gills of fish in water, which causes death in half of the exposed test population. (Test subjects are typically mice or rats for air concentrations; fish for water concentrations). Chemical is administered as a single exposure (typically 1 or 4 hours). This value gives you an idea of the relative toxicity of the material. This value applies to vapors, dusts, mists, gases, fumigants, and materials dissolved in water.

term.name: LD50
term.definition: Known as a toxicity value. The lethal dosage, amount of solid or liquid which causes death in half of the exposed population when administered orally or dermally. (The toxicity value is measured in milligrams of toxin per kilograms of body weight. Thus pounds have to be converted to kilograms.) The lower the LD<font size

term.name: Leaching
term.definition: (1) Downward movement or percolation of herbicide through a porous medium such as soil. (2) The process by which soluble matter is dissolved in groundwater and carried downward and radially through the soil, sometimes into groundwater. Example: rainwater carrying an herbicide down the slope and into another field.

term.name: Leading edge
term.definition: The part of the termite wing closest to the head. This is the part that cuts through the air first, as the termite flies forward.

term.name: Leptospirosis
term.definition: An infectious disease in domestic animals, especially cattle, swine, and dogs (also raccoons), caused by spirochetes of the genus Leptospira and characterized by fever and jaundice (2) Disease transmitted through contact with rat urine.

term.name: Lesser Grain Borer
term.definition: Mainly attacks wheat, corn, rice and millet. Both the larvae and adults are primary pests. They bore irregularly shaped holes into whole, undamaged kernels and the larvae, immature stages, may develop inside the grain. Larval and adult feeding in and on grain kernels may leave only dust and thin brown shells. A sweet, musty odor is often associated with infestations of this insect.

term.name: Lignin
term.definition: A complex polymer, the chief non-carbohydrate constituent of wood. Lignin binds to cellulose fibers and hardens and strengthens the cell walls of plants.

term.name: Line of sight supervision
term.definition: Supervision in which the supervisor can physically see the pesticide application and observe his work at all times.

term.name: Lipid synthesis inhibitors
term.definition: Herbicides that work by preventing the production of fatty acids vital to the integrity of cell membranes, and thus, growth. Examples include fenoxyprop and sethoxydim.

term.name: Live Trapping
term.definition: A means of detecting ectoparasites that may be harbored by rodents whereby the rodent is knocked out with chloroform, placed in a white porcelain tray, and its fur is combed through. Any ectoparasites dislodged by combing can be seen against the white background, collected for identification, and tested for disease.

term.name: Loreal Pit
term.definition: Sensory organ of pit vipers, such as the rattlesnake, copperhead, and water moccasin.

term.name: Lot
term.definition: One cycle of production from a mill or food processing plant; could be one or many lots per day.

term.name: Low-Volatility Pesticide
term.definition: A pesticide that doesn't evaporate under normal conditions of temperature and pressure.

term.name: Lyme Disease
term.definition: Disease vectored by deer mice, transmitted by the bite of a tick.

term.name: Lymphocytic Choriomeningitis
term.definition: A form of viral meningitis caused by a virus carried by the common house mouse.

term.name: MACOM
term.definition: Acronym for major command.

term.name: Maggot
term.definition: The larval, worm-like stage of a fly's life cycle.

term.name: MAJCOM
term.definition: Air Force Term for Major Command.

term.name: Malpighian tubules
term.definition: One of a group of long, slender excretory tubules at the anterior end of the hindgut in insects and other terrestrial arthropods.

term.name: Mandible
term.definition: This is one of the first pair of arthropod mouthpart appendages, typically a jaw-like chewing organ.

term.name: Marine borer
term.definition: A generic term for any marine organism that destroys wood. The most destructive of these organisms is the shipworm, or teredo, and the gribble. Gribbles are crustaceans and shipworms are mollusks (like clams or oysters), but both of them like to colonize wood. Shipworms (teredos) bore cylindrical holes in wood, including wooden ships! Gribbles generally colonize marine pilings. Both of these animals can degrade wood to the point that it's completely destroyed.

term.name: Mass Per Unit Volume
term.definition: Commonly an MSDS will report toxicity in terms of milligrams of toxin per liter of volume (parts per million) or milligrams of toxin per cubic meter (1,000 liters).

term.name: Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS)
term.definition: LD50 and LC50 values are found on the MSDS, not the label. The MSDS is written or printed material concerning a hazardous chemical that includes information on the chemical's identity, physical and chemical characteristics, physical and health hazards, primary routes of entry, exposure limits, whether the chemical is a carcinogen, precautions for safe handling and use, control measures, emergency and first aid procedures, the date of preparation of the MSDS or the last change to it, and the name, address, and telephone number of the manufacturer, importer, or employer distributing the MSDS.

term.name: Mating flight
term.definition: The behavior in which primary reproductives leave the colony and fly out in an attempt to mate and ultimately establish a new colony.

term.name: Mechanical control (of weeds)
term.definition: Reduction of pest plant population by hand or through the use of mechanical devices.

term.name: Mechanical Vector
term.definition: A vector that simply carries a microorganism with no replication occurring. A house fly, for example, can pick up Salmonella spp. on its feet from feces and then deposit it on human food.

term.name: Medial
term.definition: Pertaining to the middle of a segment or an appendage.

term.name: Medial line
