term.definition: A line that runs from the anterior to the posterior and divides the animal in half.

term.name: Mediterranean Flour Moth
term.definition: Found on a great variety of foodstuffs in addition to flour, grain residues (insect-infected grain, broken kernels, and dust), and various whole grains. Not as serious a pest as the Indian meal moth and some of the grain infesting beetles, but it still causes clogging of machinery with its webbing, and at times causes grain mill shut-downs. In recent times, the use of fumigants has greatly reduced the incidence of the Mediterranean flour moth.

term.name: Meniscus
term.definition: A curve in the surface of a liquid produced in response to the surface of the container or another object. For water, the curve will be concave. When reading a scale on the side of a container filled with liquid, the meniscus must be taken into account in order to obtain an accurate measurement.

term.name: Metabolic poisons
term.definition: Pesticides that kill by altering some physiological process vital to pest survival, such as nervous system function or energy metabolism

term.name: Metamorphosis
term.definition: (1) A change in form during development. The change from nymph or immature stage to adult stage. Metamorphosizing arthropods can be mistaken for an entirely different class of animals. (Example: When flea larvae (with a worm-like in appearance) are found in a pet's bed, they can be mistaken for worms. In fact, they are actually baby fleas. Another common error is to mistake grub worms, immature beetles in the larval stage, for the beneficial annelid worm. Beetles are arthropods from the Class Insecta and they feed on grass. Annelid worms are another phylum entirely. Look for the physical characteristics. A grub is an insect with a head, thorax and 3 legs. An annelid worm lacks these physical characteristics. (2) A change, or changes, in form during the growth of an animal, which adapt it to a new environment or way of living.

term.name: Metamorphosis, complete
term.definition: Of the arthropods, only animals belonging to the class Insecta go through complete metamorphosis, which involves four stages: egg, larva, pupa, and adult. In complete metamorphosis there is a dramatic change between larval and adult insects. Looking at a worm-like white grub in the compost pile, you would never imagine the iridescent June beetle that it will become. Complete metamorphosis gives arthropods a distinct advantage by allowing adults and young to use different food sources.

term.name: Metamorphosis, Incomplete
term.definition: Incomplete or gradual metamorphosis occurs in such insects as: crickets, grasshoppers, and cockroaches. The immature insect generally looks like the adult, eats the same food, and frequents the same habitat, but it is not sexually mature and lacks wings. The life cycle for gradual metamorphosis has 3 stages, with the insect going from an egg to a nymph or immature to an adult.

term.name: Metamorphosis, simple
term.definition: Of the arthropods, animals belonging to the classes, Crustacea, Arachnida, Diplopoda, and Chilopoda go through simple metamorphosis. The immature insect resembles the adult, except it's usually smaller. The arthropod molts repeatedly and grows, but the overall body form does not change over time. This means that nymphs and adults are exactly alike, except that adults are sexually mature, while nymphs are immature. Lower arthropods, such as silverfish and cockroaches always eat the same food in every life stage. Thus immature nymphs get pushed aside by hungry adults.

term.name: Methane
term.definition: A gas given off by animal waste. It can be used as fuel, but the process to turn it into fuel is very expensive, so this is not done very often. Methane is a greenhouse gas, which means that it contributes to global warming.

term.name: Metochlor
term.definition: Widely used in agriculture as a pre-emergent control for grassy weeds.

term.name: Metering knob
term.definition: The metering knob adjusts the flow of pesticide when the machine is in a liquid configuration.

term.name: Metering nozzles
term.definition: When the pressure pump is installed, the metering knob is removed and flow is governed by a metering nozzle. Pesticide passes through the nozzle into the air flow. Metering nozzles come in three sizes, small to large. Using a larger nozzle creates a faster flow.

term.name: Me-Too Pesticides
term.definition: Copy-cat pesticides manufactured under a different name. Product testing has been done for the original pesticide (Methyl Ethyl Doom manufactured by company A), thus making registration for the "Me-too" pesticide ("Jim's Methyl Ethyl Death" manufactured by company B) faster and easier.

term.name: Microbials
term.definition: A class of pesticides whose active ingredient is a microbe or a microbial protein.

term.name: Microfilariae
term.definition: Tiny thread-like larvae of filarial worms. People infected with river blindness harbor larvae in their blood, which develop into adult filarial worms which, in turn, mate and produce thousands of offspring called microfilariae.

term.name: Midges
term.definition: Any of numerous minute dipterous insect (houseflies, mosquitoes, gnats), somewhat resembling a mosquito.

term.name: Miscible
term.definition: Mixable. Once mixed, the substances will not separate or settle out. Sport drink powders are miscible; oil and vineger (as in salad dressing) are not.

term.name: Misting
term.definition: Residual liquid pesticide application in which droplet sizes are 50-100 microns.

term.name: Mites
term.definition: Tiny arachnids (small animals with 8 legs) which often live as parasites on animals, or plants or in prepared foods.

term.name: Miticides
term.definition: Pesticides that kill mites.

term.name: MMF
term.definition: Monomolecular film. As in Agnique MMF. This one-molecule thick molecular film covers water surfaces and prevents some aquatic insects, such as mosquito larvae and pupae, from breathing.

term.name: Mode of Action
term.definition: The mechanism (physical, mechanical, or biochemical) by which the pesticide affects the pest. The least toxic pesticides work physically or mechanically on the pest, as with desiccants and insecticidal soaps.

term.name: Molluscicides
term.definition: Pesticides that kill mollusks (slugs, snails, oysters, squids etc).

term.name: Mollusks
term.definition: Animals with a soft body of then enclosed in a shell, such as oysters, snails, squids, etc.

term.name: Molt
term.definition: Periodic shedding of the cuticle in arthropods or the outer skin in reptiles.

term.name: Molting
term.definition: (1) The process of shedding the exoskeleton (2) Process by which immature arthropods and other animals shed skin, etc., that will be succeeded by new growth. (During simple metamorphosis, the arthropod molts repeatedly and grows, but the overall body form does not change over time. This means that nymphs and adults are exactly alike, except that adults are sexually mature, while nymphs are immature.)

term.name: Monitoring
term.definition: Surveying the pesticide problem repeatedly over time in order to confirm or revise the proposed IPM strategy.

term.name: Monomolecular Film
term.definition: Monomolecular Film. As in Agnique MMF. This one-molecule thick molecular film covers water surfaces and prevents some aquatic insects, such as mosquito larvae and pupae, from breathing.

term.name: Morphology
term.definition: Branch of biology dealing with the form and structure of plants and animals.

term.name: Mound Drenching
term.definition: Method of ant control in which a few gallons of insecticide diluted with water are poured into an ant mound.

term.name: MSDS
term.definition: Material Safety Data Sheet. A written document that provides product users and emergency personnel with information and procedures needed for handling and working with chemicals.

term.name: Mucocutaneous
term.definition: Affecting the mucous membrane and skin surface; as in mucotaneous leishmaniasis, which eats away at the nose and mouth.

term.name: Mucocutaneous Leishmaniasis
term.definition: A form of leishmaniasis that eats away at the mucous membranes and skin of the nose and mouth.

term.name: Multiple Dose Rodenticides
term.definition: Rodenticides that kill rodents or cause serious human illness only with multiple exposures, rather than a single exposure. (Example: Warfarin, which belongs to the multi-dose Coumarins.)

term.name: Murine
term.definition: Pertaining to rats and mice.

term.name: Murine Typhus
term.definition: Disease transmitted by the bite of the Oriental rat flea.

term.name: Mutualistic
term.definition: A relationship between two organisms of different species that benefits both and harms neither.

term.name: Mutualists
term.definition: Two or more species that derive benefit from interaction, often in the form of food or defense.

term.name: Mycelium
term.definition: The hypha or mass of hyphae that make up the body of a fungus.

term.name: Myiasis
term.definition: The invasion of living tissue of animals by larvae of Diptera (flies).

term.name: National Stock Number (NSN)
term.definition: Not found on the label, but available from the Standard Pesticide List maintained on the Armed Forces Pest Management Board website. The national stock number or NSN usually doesn't change.

term.name: Natural Organic Insecticides
term.definition: Carbon-containing pesticides taken directly from the natural world, such as botanical insecticides and petroleum products.

term.name: NAVFAC
term.definition: Naval Facilities Command

term.name: Navy Environmental Health Centers (NEHC)
term.definition: The Naval Environmental Health Command (NEHC) mission is to ensure Navy and Marine Corps readiness through leadership in prevention of disease and promotion of health. We are the Navy's authoritative source for FHP support, providing a full spectrum of preventive health services.

term.name: Necrosis
term.definition: A type of cell death in which cells swell and break open, release their contents and can damage neighboring cells and provoke inflammation.

term.name: Necrotizing Venom
term.definition: Venom that attacks living tissues around the site of a wound, rather than attacking whole body systems. Generally there is no sensation of pain, initially. The brown recluse spider injects necrotizing venom with its bite.

term.name: Nematicides
term.definition: Pesticides designed to kill or otherwise control nematodes.

term.name: Nematodes
term.definition: (1) Worms in long, cylindrical unsegmented bodies, such as hookworms, pinworm, etc. (2) Non-segmented roundworms belonging to the phylum Nematoda--one of the most successful of all animal groups. Most nematodes live in soil, feeding on decaying organic matter, other microbes, or plant roots. Nematodes that parasitize people are called filarial worms.

term.name: Nematology
term.definition: The study of nematodes, or roundworms. Many nematodes cause disease in living things and problems in agriculture.

term.name: NEPA
term.definition: The National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) requires that the environmental impact of all major federal actions be considered before implementing an installation pest management plan.

term.name: Nettles
term.definition: Plants covered with stinging hairs as a form of defense against being eaten.

term.name: Nettling
term.definition: Stinging or irritating--as in nettling spines of urticating caterpillars.

term.name: Neurotoxic Venom
term.definition: Venom that attacks the nervous system, causing reactions such as muscle spasms, pain, irregular heartbeat. Poisonous snakes, most scorpions, and widow spiders inject neurotoxic venom with their bite.

term.name: Neurotoxin
term.definition: A substance that inhibits, damages, or destroys the tissues of the nervous system.

term.name: Nitrogen-fixing
term.definition: The conversion of atmospheric nitrogen into compounds that plants and other organisms can assimilate, usually accomplished by microorganisms.

term.name: Nits
term.definition: The eggs of a louse.

term.name: Non-Appropriated Fund Activities
term.definition: For-profit operations that fund themselves (and get no appropriations from Congress), such as: the golf course, bowling alley, commissary, and PX. (Golf courses are the largest single users of pesticides in the DOD.)

term.name: Non-Repellant Pesticides
term.definition: Inorganic insecticides are non-repellant, especially to cockroaches

term.name: Nonselective Contact Herbicide
term.definition: Herbicide chemicals that are capable of killing most plants, grasses or broadleaf. There are 4 types: soil fumigants, soil sterilants, systemic non-persistent foliage applied chemicals, and non-persistent foliage applied chemicals.

term.name: Non-social Predators
term.definition: The vast majority of scorpions are nonsocial, solitary animals that interact only at birth, during courtship, or for cannibalism.

term.name: Non-traceable pesticides
term.definition: Pesticide purchased and used by individuals in Family Housing or sometimes in the offices around the installation, and not reported.

term.name: Nozzle calibration
term.definition: a technique for converting gallons per acre, which are difficult to measure, into an easily measured unit, gallons per minute.

term.name: Nymphs
term.definition: The immature stage of an insect that does not have a pupal stage, such as a cockroach. Nymphs look similar to adults.

term.name: Obligate Parasites
term.definition: Parasites that can only survive as parasites, that is, by feeding on a live host; they have no alternate means of surviving. Example: ticks must parasitise living animals, such as human beings, because blood is their only source of food.

term.name: Obligately Intracellular Parasite
term.definition: A parasite that can only develop inside a living cell, such as Rickettsia rickettsii, the pathogen that causes Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever.

term.name: Off-target application
term.definition: when non-target shrub or pest is killed, e.g., shrubbery dies after the lawn has been treated for weeds.

term.name: Omnivores
term.definition: An animal that eats both plants and other animals; domestic rodents are omnivores.

term.name: Ootheca
term.definition: A type of egg mass made by any member of a variety of species (usually insects or mollusks) and containing many eggs surrounded by a foam of protein which may then harden into a tough casing for protection. Notable ootheca-making insects are the mantid (praying mantis) and cockroach.

term.name: Opportunistic Pathogen
term.definition: Pathogen that will spread to almost any living organism, such as, Fransisella tulernsis, the bacterium which causes Tularemia.

term.name: O-ring
term.definition: A round rubber washer or gasket that is compressed to create a watertight or liquid-proof seal, typically in a compression fitting. O-rings are made of rubber or plastic, and they can dry out and crack. Some grease, or a drop of oil, keeps them pliable.

term.name: Oral (and dermal) toxins
term.definition: Toxins ingested through the mouth or absorbed through the skin. Measured using LD50 values.

term.name: Oral absorption
term.definition: Occurs when a toxin is eaten or drunk, as in the case of children eating rodent or insect bait.

term.name: Order
term.definition: A subdivision of a class, containing a group of related families.

term.name: Order Acarina
term.definition: Mites (and ticks) belong to this order.

term.name: Order Coleoptera
term.definition: Beetles belong to this order. Coleoptera means sheath wings, wings that protect the body of the insect.

term.name: Order Lepidoptera
term.definition: Moths belong to this order. Lepidoptera means scaly wings.

term.name: Organelles
term.definition: Literally, the term means "Little organs". Inside a cell, there are various structures that perform specific functions, much like the multicellular organs of our body carry out certain tasks.

term.name: Organic compounds (rodenticides)
term.definition: A class of rodenticides, either natural or synthetic, which contain carbon. Virtually all currently used rodenticides, both anti-coagulants and non-anticoagulants, are organic compounds.

term.name: Organic Insecticides
term.definition: Contain carbon

term.name: Organometalic
term.definition: A chemical formed when a metal or metalloid binds to the carbon in an organic compound. Some oil-borne wood preservatives, such as copper chromated arsenate, are organometalics.

term.name: Organophosphates
term.definition: Along with organophosphates, carbamates are highly toxic and the most dangerous group of pesticides. Carbamates and organophosphates kill by cholinesterase inhibition, and attack the nervous system, causing loss of muscular control. (Injuries from carbamates are more easily reversible than those of organophosphates.)

term.name: Overwintered
term.definition: Insects that survive the winter.

term.name: Oviposit
term.definition: To lay eggs; a term usually used to define egg-laying by insects, who have a specialized structure called an ovipositor.

term.name: Ovipositor
term.definition: Specialized egg-laying organ which in most insects is formed from outgrowths of the eighth and ninth abdominal segment. Extreme forms of ovipositor occur in the sawflies, ichneumons, and wood wasps, where it may be longer than the entire body, and equipped apically with saw teeth to aid penetration of hard plant tissues.

term.name: Palps
term.definition: Male sexual structures used to identify the hobo spider under the microscope.

term.name: Parasitic fungi
term.definition: Fungi that live on, or in another living thing (called the "Host" organism), and which cause either disease or reduced vitality in the host.

term.name: Pathogen
term.definition: A disease-causing organism.

term.name: Parthenogenesis
term.definition: Reproduction by development of an unfertilized gamete

term.name: Pathologists
term.definition: Investigates structural and functional changes in tissues and organs which are caused by pesticidal compounds.

term.name: Peak Egg Hatch Period
term.definition: Many insect pests lay eggs during limited periods each year. This results in large, and predictable hatches. This information may be used in planning and conducting effective pest control.

term.name: Pedicel
term.definition: A constriction between the thorax and abdomen found in insects in the order hymenoptera (ants, bees, wasps, saw flies). This constriction is actually part of the abdomen, not a separate anatomical part.

term.name: Pediculicide
term.definition: A pesticide used to kill lice.

term.name: Pediculosis
term.definition: Head lice, a disease treated with pediculicide. Head lice do not vector other diseases, they are a disease themselves.

term.name: Pedipalps
term.definition: A pair of claws on the scorpion's cephalothorax or front end used for grabbing prey and holding it in place as the scorpion sinks its fangs in; also used by for mating by mature males.

term.name: Pendamethelin
term.definition: One of the oldest pre-emergent herbicides. Can be used, for example, on corn seedlings.

term.name: Penetrant
term.definition: An adjuvant that enhances the ability of a liquid to enter into the pores of a substrate or penetrate a surface layer.

term.name: Penetrator Species
term.definition: One of several stored product pests, such as the saw-toothed beetle, that readily chew through packages into stored food.

term.name: Percolation
term.definition: Seepage of a liquid, like water, through a porous body or surface, e.g., water percolating into ground water; pesticides seeping into drinking water. Rain may cause percolation as when pesticides wash down through sandy soil into underground water supplies.

term.name: Perennial
term.definition: Plant that lives for an indefinite period of years.

term.name: Perimeter Baiting
term.definition: Baiting strategy for either single or multiple-dose rodenticides that requires knowledge of rodent pathways. Bait is set around the perimeter of the building to keep rodents out. The problem is that it is hard to do, as surveillance of rodents is required.

term.name: Persistent Chemical
term.definition: A chemical or group of chemicals that are stable under normal situations and do not readily break down in the environment by microorganisms, heat, enzymes, or ultraviolet light.

term.name: Pest
term.definition: Any injurious or annoying organism (plant, animal, fungus, virus, or microscopic organism).

term.name: Pest Controller
term.definition: (Pesticide Applicator) Person who applies chemicals to manage or control pests.

term.name: Pest management consultant
term.definition: Usually a graduate entomologist or agronomist who manages and directs the pest management program of an entire command or agency, providing policy, guidance and oversight.

term.name: Pest management program
term.definition: The prevention and control of disease vectors and pests that may adversely affect the DOD mission or military operations; the health and well-being of people, structures, materiel or property. (From DODI 4150.7, DoD Pest Management Program).

term.name: Pest Quarantine
term.definition: Geographic isolations of pest organisms imposed to prevent the spread of disease and/or destruction,. e.g., browntree snakes.

term.name: Pesticide
term.definition: The term applies to many kinds of ingredients in products, such as insect repellants, weed killers, disinfectants and swimming pool chemicals, which are designed to prevent, destroy, repel or reduce pests of any sort. Any substance, including biological control agents that may prevent, destroy, repel, or mitigate pests. If a product is sold as a pesticide, it must be registered at the federal level by the EPA and the state level by an agency such as the state's department of agriculture. EPA-registered pesticides must carry labels describing the proper dosage and frequency of application for the control of specific pests, as well as a list of active ingredients and other pertinent information.

term.name: Pesticide applicator
term.definition: Any individual who applies pesticides or supervises the use of pesticides by others (From DODI 4150.7, DoD Pest Management Program).

term.name: Pesticide categories
term.definition: Categories (I-IV, with Cat I being the most toxic). The categories indicate whether an antidote statement is required on the label and where (on the front or on the back). These categories are linked to levels of toxicity. (See Cat I, Cat II, Cat III, Cat IV.).

term.name: Pesticide residue
term.definition: The pesticide component left over long after the pesticide application is completed.

term.name: Pesticide resistance
term.definition: (1) Phenomenon by which target plant, herb, or rodent develops tolerance for the poison, such that it no longer is effective in eradicating it. An organism's defenses against the action of a pesticide that render it partly or wholly ineffective. Some organisms are able to metabolize or otherwise deactivate specific pesticides. Tolerance developed by pests to pesticides such that the pesticide loses its ability to control pests. (2) Undesirable result of repeated application of one pesticide exclusively on the same active site, e.g., exclusive use of the organophosphate (Malathion) for mosquito control at a given site. The pest population becomes less susceptible to the effects of the pesticide. (To avoid pesticide resistance use targeted application, pesticide rotation, and no-chemical measures, where possible.).

term.name: Pesticide runoff
term.definition: What occurs when pesticides wash across the ground in rainwater or other moving water. Pesticides can make their way to lakes, rivers, and streams in two basic ways. They can hitch a ride with eroding soil by adsorbing, or attaching, to soil particles. Or, they can dissolve in runoff water and move with the water as it flows across the surface.

term.name: Pesticide tank
term.definition: Receptacle for liquid and granular pesticides.

term.name: Pesticide tolerances
term.definition: Amount of pesticide residue, which is considered safe in good products. Any amount exceeding the tolerance is considered harmful.

term.name: Pesticide tube
term.definition: Conducts liquid pesticides from the spray tank to the misting nozzle.

term.name: Petroleum-Based Pesticides
term.definition: Like horticultural (or dormant) oils, they are made from lightweight petroleum. A lot of pesticides are mixed with petroleum.) Exposure causes nausea, coughing, vomiting, weakness, dizziness, slow and shallow breathing.

term.name: Pheromone traps
term.definition: the use of pheromones to trap insects, a form of bio-control; entomologists duplicate insect sex pheromones and use them in traps to catch the male insects.

term.name: Pheromone
term.definition: A chemical substance that conveys information to and produces specific responses in certain animals.

term.name: Pheromone trail
term.definition: A type of pheromone used by social insects and some lepidopterans to recruit others of its species to a food source.

term.name: Phloem
term.definition: Greek word for bark. Refers to the living vascular tissue located just beneath the outer bark of trees that moves manufactured sugars from foliage to other growing parts of the plant, especially the roots.

term.name: Photoperiodicity
term.definition: (1) The relative amount of daylight (or night) during a day. (2) Reaction in an invertebrate to the relative amount of daylight or darkness. (Hibernation is triggered by photoperiodicity.)

term.name: Photosynthesis inhibitors
term.definition: Herbicides that inhibit the plant's food production system by binding to specific sites within the chloroplast. Plants rapidly starve and die. Examples include atrazine, prometon, diuron and bromocil.

term.name: Phylum
term.definition: This is one of the dozen or so divisions in the animal kingdom. Class a subdivision of a phylum, containing a group of related orders.

term.name: Phylum Arthropoda
term.definition: Consists of the 5 classes of arthropods: 1. Diploda (millipedes), 2. Chilopoda (centipedes), 3. Insecta (insects), 4. Arachnida (spiders, ticks and scorpions), and 5. Crustacea (shrimp and lobsters).

term.name: Physical tools (IPM)
term.definition: Use of physical forces (heat, cold, radioactivity) to control pests usually in confined spaces.

term.name: Physogastry
term.definition: A condition in arthropods in which the females ovaries and fat bodies enlarge, causing abdominal enlargement.

term.name: Phytotoxic
term.definition: Poisonous to plants. A lot of common materials, such as oils, easily kill plants. Over application of pesticides may also have a phytotoxic effect, even if the pesticides are insecticides and not designed to harm plants at all.

term.name: Pi
term.definition: The ratio of the circumference to the diameter of a circle; a number having a value to eight decimal places of 3.14159265 and usually rounded off to 3.14

term.name: Pigment inhibitors
term.definition: Herbicides that stop the synthesis of carotenoid, a photosynthetic pigment important in plant food production. Plants exposed to pigment inhibitors turn white and soon die. Examples include: clomazone, norfluazon, benzofenap, and amitrole.

term.name: Piscicides
term.definition: Pesticides that kill fish

term.name: Piston pump
term.definition: A pump in which motion and pressure are applied to the fluid by a reciprocating piston in a cylinder. Also known as reciprocating pump.

term.name: Plant growth regulators
term.definition: Herbicides with multiple modes of action. Their primary mode of action is not known. They have properties similar to auxin (a growth hormone produced by plants). They interfere with nucleic acid metabolism and normal transport systems in plants by induced massive cell proliferation. Examples include "2,4-D", dicamba, and clopyralid.

term.name: Plasmodium
term.definition: Parasitic protozoan, belonging to the genus Plasmodium; pathogen (agent) which causes malaria

term.name: Poison (Toxicant)
term.definition: A substance that causes injury, or illness, or death; usually effective even in very small dosages. Remember that the dose makes the poison.

term.name: Polymer
term.definition: ""A plastic-like material produced from chemical ""Monomers"""" which in turn have been produced from alcohols and petrochemicals. Certain polymers are used as latex paint and caulk binders. The binder's polymer particles are small and carried in water. The lignin in wood is a polymer.

term.name: Positive Displacement
term.definition: A mechanism by which gas or fluid is displaced, or pushed, out of a chamber. Positive displacement pumps conduct fluid into a chamber, and then use a piston to push that liquid from the chamber and into a discharge pipe.

term.name: Post-Emergent Herbicide
term.definition: A chemical applied as an herbicide to the foliage of established weeds.

term.name: Posterior
term.definition: Hind part or in the rear.

term.name: Precipitate
term.definition: A solid substance that forms in a liquid and settles to the bottom of a container. A material that no longer remains in suspension.

term.name: Predacides
term.definition: Pesticides that kill vertebrates.

term.name: Pre-Emergent Herbicides
term.definition: A chemical applied as an herbicide to the seedling root of the weed before it emerges from the ground as an established weed. Pre-emergent herbicides are virtually insoluble, or they'll wash down to the soil surface, but not below the surface. They barely react with water at all.

term.name: Pressure
term.definition: The force exerted on a given area. In the U.S., pressure is often measured in units of pounds per square inch.

term.name: Primary reproductives
term.definition: The fertile, winged termite caste that takes mating flights in an effort to establish new colonies.

term.name: Primer bulb
term.definition: Used to "Prime" the engine just before starting by injecting a little gasoline into the carburetor.

term.name: Primitive termites
term.definition: Termites in 3 of the 4 termite families (Hodotermitidai, Kalotermitidae, and Rhinotermitidae) which are characterized by relatively simple caste division and development compared to termites in the family Termitidae. Subterranean, dampwood, and drywood termites are considered primitive termites.

term.name: Private certification
term.definition: A certification that authorizes farmers to use or supervise the use of restricted use pesticides on their own farm to produce an agricultural commodity.

term.name: Proboscis
term.definition: Also known as a beak; the elongated, protruding insect mouth parts, adapted for sucking or piercing. When taking a blood meal, female files use the prosboscis to cut into the victim's skin.

term.name: Producer
term.definition: The company that manufactures a pesticide. The registrant listed on the label may not necessarily be the producer/manufacturer.

term.name: Prolegs
term.definition: The fleshy leg-like structures on the caterpillar which occur on the abdomen behind the actual front legs.

term.name: Promenade-a-deux
term.definition: French for walking in pairs; term used to describe scorpion mating in which male deposits a spermatophore on a rock or other surface, then guides the female into a position in which she can take up the spermatophore and be inseminated.

term.name: Pronotum
term.definition: (1) The dorsal body plate of the first section of the thorax, frequently enlarged in many insects, such as cockroaches; it acts as a shield covering the head. (2) The upper or dorsal surface of the first segment of the thorax. This segment bears the anterior (first pair) of legs but no wings.

term.name: Propellant
term.definition: A gas, as a fluorocarbon, that serves as a vehicle for discharging the contents of an aerosol container. Propellants fall into the category of inert ingredients, so many aerosol insecticides do not list them specifically. Not all propellants are fluorocarbons, but they are all pressurized gasses of some type.

term.name: Prophylactic
term.definition: (See Prophylaxis)

term.name: Prophylaxis
term.definition: Anything that prevents or contributes to the prevention of disease, such as certain drugs, fresh air, rest, and proper nutrition.

term.name: Proportion
term.definition: A relationship between two equal ratios, or fractions, used to solve for missing or unknown quantities. Note that all proportions are equations.

term.name: Proprietary Secrets
term.definition: Trade secrets, which are the legal property of the manufacturer

term.name: Protocerebrum
term.definition: The primitive anterior cerebral vesicle; the first part of the arthropod brain. The arthropod "brain" is actually a collection of ganglia compressed into a single organ made up of the: protocerebrum, deuterocerebrum, and tritocerebrum.

term.name: Protozoan
term.definition: Single-celled parasite that can cause disease, that is, serve as a pathogen (agent).

term.name: Proximal
term.definition: Near the body. The part of a segment or appendage that is closest to the body.

term.name: Pseudergate
term.definition: "Known" also as false workers; this is an intermediate termite stage that can molt into virtually any of the main castes; worker, soldier and reproductive.

term.name: PSI
term.definition: Pounds per square inch; unit used to measure pressure, such as the force of air inflating a tire, or the force exerted by moving fluids like water coming out of a hose, pressure washer, or pesticide sprayer.

term.name: Psittacosis
term.definition: Also known as parrot fever; a bacterial disease contracted by inhaling dried bird secretions that can lead to pneumonia.

term.name: Pulsed Baiting
term.definition: Baiting strategy for single-dose rodenticides. Baits are set out in pulses or spaced intervals, for example, every 2 weeks. In this way, each pulse removes a different group of rodents.

term.name: Pupa
term.definition: (1) An insect in the non-feeding, usually immobile, transformation stage between the larva and adult. (2) Intermediate stage between the larva and the adult; this stage is generally inactive and encased in a case or cocoon.

term.name: Pupal stage
term.definition: The nonfeeding stage between the larva and adult in insects with complete metamorphosis, during which the larva typically undergoes complete transformation within a protective cocoon or hardened case.

term.name: Pupate
term.definition: To become a pupa, that is, an insect in the non-feeding , usually immobile, transformation state between the larval and adult stages.

term.name: Pupation
term.definition: The process of changing into a pupa, the non-feeding, usually immobile, transformation state between the larval and adult insect stages.

term.name: PVNTMED SVC
term.definition: Preventive Medicine Service

term.name: Pyrethroids
term.definition: Copies, or analogs, of the botanical pesticide, pyrethrum.

term.name: Pyrethrum and pyrethroids
term.definition: Exposure causes skin irritation, pre-asthmatic reactions, hay-fever-like symptoms, and convulsions.

term.name: Quarantine
term.definition: A strict isolation imposed to prevent the spread of a disease, or pest.

term.name: Queen
term.definition: The king and queen are primary reproductives that have managed to mate and begin a colony. (Alates who make it good.)

term.name: Questing
term.definition: A tick behavior consisting of climbing onto vegetation, usually along animal trails, and extending their front two legs. When a passing animal brushes against the questing tick, the tick grabs and holds on, then looks for a feeding site.

term.name: Quinine
term.definition: A chemical compound which serves as a natural cure for malaria. Found in the bark of cinchona trees.

term.name: Radius
term.definition: A straight line from the center to the perimeter of a circle (or from the center to the surface of a sphere.)

term.name: Rain Fast
term.definition: Phenomenon that occurs within a few hours of herbicide application, whereby the herbicide becomes impervious to the potential diluting effect of rain.

term.name: Rat Bite Fever
term.definition: Rat-borne disease transmitted by contact with rat saliva. Rats leave their saliva in the bowls or cups of your pantry, then you unknowingly drink out of them.

term.name: Red Flour Beetle
term.definition: One of the Tribolium flour beetles; The red and confused flour beetles live in the same environment and compete for resources. The red flour beetle may fly, especially before a storm, but the confused flour beetle does not fly. Very common pest infesting flour mills, warehouses, and grocery stores; they also feed on grain, beans, dried fruits, nuts, chocolate, and other foods in the house.

term.name: Registered
term.definition: Refers to a pesticide with official sanction from a governing agency such as the USDA (until 1972) or EPA (after 1972), or a state (after 1978).

term.name: Registrant
term.definition: The party that registers the pesticide label. The registrant may not be the actual manufacturer. In this case, the label must specify the limited role of the registrant e.g., packed for, distributed by, sold by (to show that the name listed is not that of the producer).

term.name: Registration Number
term.definition: Like a social security number for pesticides. Always preceded by the words, EPA Registration Number. This number is unique to a particular pesticide made by a certain manufacturer. The same pesticide made by different manufacturers will have different registration numbers. Used as a tracking number on pesticide inventories, reports of pesticide usage, and incident reports.

term.name: Regulating flow rate
term.definition: Increasing or decreasing flow rate.

term.name: Relapsing Fever
term.definition: (1) An infection caused by bacteria in the Borrelia family. There are two major forms. Tick-borne relapsing fever (TBRF) is transmitted by the Ornithodoros tick and occurs in Africa, Spain, Saudi Arabia, Asia, and certain areas in the western US and Canada. Louse-borne relapsing fever (LBRF), which is transmitted by body lice, is prevalent in the developing world (Asia, Africa, and Central and South America). (2) A rickettsial disease vectored by lice and ticks, causing a periodic (every 3 - 5 days) fever.

term.name: Repellants
term.definition: Any substance such as lime, oil, etc. used to drive away pests or other insects.

term.name: Repugnatorial Fluid
term.definition: Toxic, carcinogenic substance, specifically, benzoquinones, nasty yellowish substances that give a bad taste and odor to stored food; emitted from the glands of flour beetles (and other arthropods, such as millipedes).

term.name: Repugnatorial Glands
term.definition: Located at the base of the legs of millipedes, the gland squirts repugnatorial fluid at a distance of about one foot. This fluid is dangerous to the eyes and skin.

term.name: Reservoir
term.definition: Diseased animal in which the pathogen multiplies and can then be passed on. For plague, the reservoir is usually wild rodent populations. For Rocky Mountain Fever, ticks maintain the disease within themselves and also transmit or vector it. Just as a water reservoir stores water, a group of organisms can store pathogens. These organisms can then pass on the pathogen, either directly or through another vector. Reservoir animals may or may not be immune to the pathogen.

term.name: Residual Liquid Treatment
term.definition: The application of residual liquid pesticide (normally a spray or mist) to some kind of surface where the pesticide stays.

term.name: Residual Solid Treatment
term.definition: The application of residual solid pesticide (usually a dust or granule) to some kind of surface where the pesticide stays.

term.name: Residual Treatment
term.definition: A type of pesticide application intended to last and provide control over a period of time. Invariably, these treatments are applied to surfaces, such as floors, walls, and soil, or into a substance such as wood. This contrasts with airspace treatments, which are applied into the air and last no more than a few hours.

term.name: Residue
term.definition: The pesticide that remains in the environment in food, structures (buildings), soil, water, etc. after an application

term.name: Resins
term.definition: Any one of a class of yellowish brown solid inflammable substances, of vegetable origin. Resins exude from trees in combination with essential oils, gums, etc., and in a liquid or semiliquid state.

term.name: Resistance
term.definition: A genetic change in response to selection by a pesticide, resulting in the development of strains capable of surviving a dose lethal to most individuals in a normal population. Resistance may develop in insects, weeds, or pathogens

term.name: Restricted Use Pesticide
term.definition: A pesticide that can be purchased only by certified pesticide applicator and used only by certified pesticide applicators or persons directly under their supervision. Not available for use for the general public because of the high toxicities and/or environmental hazards. A pesticide that the EPA or State Regulatory agency determines to have the potential to cause unreasonable adverse effects on the environment or human health, when applied in accordance with the labeled direction for use, and has additional regulatory restrictions associated with it.

term.name: Resurveillance
term.definition: a more detailed survey that occurs after the initial assessment, once you have confirmed that there truly is a pest management problem requiring an IPM strategy. During the resurvey, you return to the area to look at things in greater deta il to locate the habita t, determine population size and identify the a ttract ant.

term.name: Retention rate
term.definition: Amount of preservative (measured in pounds per cubic foot) that remains in wood after treatment is complete. This is a function of the type of treatment, the type of preservative, and the wood. Wood that's exposed to soil or water needs more preservative, so higher retention rates are used for wood that's in ground contact, or foundations.

term.name: Rhizomorphs
term.definition: A thick mass of hyphae forming a root-like structure characteristic of many fungi.

term.name: Rice Weevils
term.definition: Both granary and rice weevils, often known as "Snout weevils", penetrate and feed on the internal portions of whole grains during the larval (immature) stage, making early detection of infestations difficult. Usually found in grain storage or processing plants, infesting wheat, oats, rye, barley, rice, and corn. Although not often found in the home, sometimes they infest table beans, acorns, chestnuts, birdseed, sunflower seeds, and ornamental corn. Rarely found in macaroni and spaghetti.

term.name: Rickettsial Disease
term.definition: Diseases caused by pathogens from the genus-species, rickettsias spp; these pathogens are considered intracellular parasites--like viruses, they cannot live outside a living cell; almost all tick-borne disease are rickettsial.

term.name: Rinsate
term.definition: The contaminated water resulting from triple-rinsing empty pesticide containers.

term.name: Ripple effect
term.definition: Phenomenon in which any single act of biotic simplification (removing any part of an ecosystem) leads to unexpected systemic consequences (one change leading to a series of changes) for the entire ecosystem. For example: pollinated crops failing after widespread mosquito control.

term.name: Risk
term.definition: The probability that an adverse effect will result from an exposure to a chemical.

term.name: Risk Formula
term.definition: In toxicology, risk is considered to be the product of risk times exposure. Because exposure is controllable, so is risk.

term.name: Rodenticides
term.definition: Pesticides designed to kill rodents are highly toxic to humans and come in 3 forms: organics, inorganics (such as zinc phosphide), or the newer anti-coagulant rodenticides. Anticoagulants inhibit blood-clotting leading to internal hemorrhage; inorganics destroy entire organ systems; organics are convulsants that induce heart attack.

term.name: Roosting
term.definition: A special word for avian slumber; birds often roost on a twig or branch in a sheltered area where they sit up straight and allow themselves to fall asleep. For safety and early warning purposes, birds are often found roosting in groups.

term.name: Running rough
term.definition: An engine with an unstable combustion process. This instability may result from several different factors, but most likely the air/fuel mixture is incorrect. For example, leaving the choke closed after an engine has started will restrict air flow into the engine so that the fuel to air mixture is too rich. Without sufficient air for proper combustion, the engine will stutter and fuel will flood the spark plugs. Opening the choke will restore the proper fuel/air mixture and the engine will run smoothly.

term.name: S.
term.definition: Solution. As in Orthene S

term.name: Sample Eaters
term.definition: Rats and mice tend to take a bite of one food and then they move on to something else. This is probably a survival mechanism that helps them, to some extent, to keep them from eating anything toxic.

term.name: Sample Feeders
term.definition: (1) Animals that eat by tasting several of the foods available to them. By sampling and discarding foods, they spoil much more food than they actually eat. (2) Rats and mice tend to take a bite of one food and then they move on to something else. This is probably a survival mechanism that helps them, to some extent, to keep them from eating anything toxic.

term.name: Saprophytes
term.definition: Fungi and other organisms that receive nourishment from dead organic material.

term.name: Saturation Baiting
term.definition: Baiting strategy for multiple-dose rodenticides in which food is made constantly available. Spoiled or consumed baits are replaced daily. Baiting stations are spaced as follows: 15-50 ft. apart for rats, 10 ft. apart for mice

term.name: Savanna (Savannah)
term.definition: A tropical or subtropical grassland containing scattered trees and drought-resistant undergrowth. Habitat of most tsetse flies.

term.name: Scientific Name
term.definition: Consists of the genus and species. (e.g., the scientific name for the Monarch butterfly is Danaus plexippus; the scientific name for humans is homo sapiens.)

term.name: Scorpionism
term.definition: Poisoning by scorpions

term.name: Seasoning
term.definition: A process of reducing the moisture content of wood, usually this is done by air-drying or kiln drying. Wood treated with water-borne preservatives must be seasoned before using so that shrinkage can occur.

term.name: Secondary Pest
term.definition: (See Emergent Pest)

term.name: Secondary poisoning
term.definition: Unintended poisoning of non-target animals that occurs when non-target animal consumes a pest which has been killed or sickened by a pesticide, e.g., birds that die after farms spray for grasshoppers

term.name: Secondary Repellants
term.definition: Chemicals applied to crops or feed that don't immediately repel animals. Animals eating the treated food get sick and then associate their illness with the food

term.name: Seedling growth inhibitors
term.definition: Herbicides normally used to control plants during germination. The site of action may be the root or the shoot, but the result is a reduction of new growth. Most of these herbicides inhibit cell division, or mitosis

term.name: Seedling Root
term.definition: The Radicle, or embryonic root, is the first structure to emerge from a germinating seed. Pre-emergent herbicides must be applied to the seedling root.

term.name: Segmentation
term.definition: Division into parts. In humans, the spinal column is highly segmented into vertebrae. Arthropods are visibly divided into body parts or segments. Millipedes are highly segmented with 47-197 legs

term.name: Selective Herbicides
term.definition: Herbicides that are toxic to some plants, but have little or no effect on other species.

term.name: Self-help
term.definition: Pest management carried out by installation personnel do-it-yourselfers e.g., family housing occupants, using pest control materials (mainly glue traps, fly swatters, and very low toxicity pesticides, such as ant baits). Self-help usage must be accounted for in the installation pest management plan.

term.name: Serotypes
term.definition: The strain of a disease. There are four serotypes or strains of the genus Flavivirus, the agent or pathogen that causes Dengue fever. There is no cross-immunity from one strain of the disease to the other. If you catch one serotype, you are not immune from catching the others.

term.name: Setae
term.definition: Specialized nettling spines; defense mechanism of caterpillar larva. Spines are hollow and filled with toxins from poison-gland cells. When these little needles break off, they release the toxin. Setae may penetrate human hide, or the toxins might just spill out on skin.

term.name: Shipworms
term.definition: Also known as teredos; a very destructive mollusk (in the same phylum as clams and oysters) that colonizes and destroys wood in marine environments. Shipworms generally drill cylindrical holes in wood, including wooden ships. Shipworms (teredos) and the unrelated gribble are referred to as "marine borers" for their wood-destroying habits.

term.name: Silage
term.definition: Chopped green material, usually green corn, fermented in silos, then fed to animals in the winter.

term.name: Single Dose Rodenticides
term.definition: Highly toxic rodenticides that kill rodents or cause serious human illness with just a single exposure, rather after multiple exposures. (Example: diphacinone, one of the inandiones.)

term.name: Site of application
term.definition: This can be a crop or even an animal. Pesticide may be applied to any pest whose site of application is listed, even if the pest, itself, is not specifically mentioned on the label.

term.name: Social Insects
term.definition: (1) Insects that take bait back to colony before dying. (2) Insects, such as ants, termites bees, and most wasps, that live in colonies. They divide the labor in the nest so that different castes have different functions like reproduction, food-gathering and nest maintenance, and colony defense. These societies are almost completely female. Males only exist to fertilize the egg-laying queen. They usually die soon afterward.

term.name: Soil Fumigant
term.definition: An herbicide that forms a gas toxic to plants, animals, and microorganisms.

term.name: Soil Solarization
term.definition: Sterilizing soil by covering it with clear plastic and letting sunshine heat it up to lethal temperatures. This technique may help replace the soil fumigant methyl bromide, which is being phased out because of its ozone depleting effects.

term.name: Soil Sterilant
term.definition: A chemical or agent that prevents the growth of all organisms present in the soil.

term.name: Soldier
term.definition: A termite caste modified for colony defense. Modifications include large mandibles used for fighting and a large head. Soldiers are unable to feed themselves.

term.name: Solubility
term.definition: For pesticides, the active ingredient's ability to stick to vegetation or insect bodies.

term.name: Soluble
term.definition: A substance that will dissolve in a liquid carrier.

term.name: Solution
term.definition: A mixture of two or more substances that are completely dissolved.

term.name: Solvent
term.definition: A material having the property to dissolve another to form a solution.

term.name: Space Treatment
term.definition: A type of pesticide application in which the pesticide is applied to an airspace where the pest lives or will pass. Pests entering this airspace will inhale or contact the pesticide. Space treatments last a very short time and provide no lasting control.

term.name: Specialized Phase
term.definition: In pesticide applicator training, this refers to training in any one of the ten commercial certification categories. In DoD, the specialized phase may cover category 2 (forestry), 3 (ornamental and turf), 5 (aquatic), 6 (right of way), 7 (industrial, institutional, structural and health related), 8 (public health) and 9 (aerial).

term.name: Species
term.definition: A group of individuals or populations similar in structure and physiology and capable of interbreeding and producing fertile offspring. They are different in structure and physiology from other groups and do not normally interbreed with them.

term.name: Sphincter
term.definition: A circular band of voluntary or involuntary muscle that surrounds orifices or openings in hollow organs, such as the stomach and intestine.

term.name: Spinosad
term.definition: Nervous system disruptor, derived from yeast. Used to control destructive caterpillars in turf grass and ornamental plants.

term.name: Spiracle
term.definition: An opening through which air or water passes in the act of respiration

term.name: Spiracles
term.definition: All arachnids are terrestrial or land living arthropods. They breathe by either spiracles or book lungs. The spiracles are breathing holes on the body surface that take air to individual cells.

term.name: Spittle
term.definition: Sticky foam produced when excess water is secreted

term.name: Spores
term.definition: The reproductive unit of fungi. Spores function in the same way that seeds do for higher plants.

term.name: SPP
term.definition: Abbreviation for the word "Species"; used to indicate that the insect has been identified only to the Genus level. (As in: Culex spp)

term.name: Spray
term.definition: Residual liquid pesticide application in which droplet sizes are 100 microns or greater.

term.name: Spreader
term.definition: An adjuvant used to enhance the spread of a pesticide over a treated surface, thus improving the coverage.

term.name: Squared
term.definition: Multiplying a number by itself, or raising the number to the second power. Area is measured in units squared.

term.name: Starter grip
term.definition: Link between the operator's hand and the starter rope.

term.name: Steroids
term.definition: A drug that enhances muscle growth if taken along with rigorous physical training and a high protein diet.

term.name: Sticker
term.definition: An adjuvant used to improve the adherence of spray droplets to a plant, animal, or other treated surface.

term.name: Stomach poison
term.definition: A pesticide that must be eaten in order to have any toxic effect.

term.name: Stop cock
term.definition: Regulates pesticide flow.

term.name: Structural wood
term.definition: Lumber; furniture, flooring, wood paneling (some beetles, like lyctids, seem to prefer structural wood; others, like the cerambycids, typically feed on live trees and end up killing them in the process).

term.name: Structural wood
term.definition: Wood used to construct a building of some kind

term.name: Stylet
term.definition: A small, stiff, needlelike organ or appendage

term.name: Subcutaneous
term.definition: Lying under the skin, as tissue; living below the several layers of the skin, as certain parasites

term.name: Sublimation
term.definition: Process by which a solid is converted to a gas without apparent liquefaction, e.g., dry ice (solid carbon dioxide) becomes a gas without passing through a liquid phase. In pest management, solid fumigants like aluminum phosphide become a gas without becoming a liquid.

term.name: Sump
term.definition: Pit, well, or the like, in which water or other liquid is collected.

term.name: Superfund site
term.definition: Uncontrolled or abandoned place with hazardous waste that can possibly affect local ecosystems or people.

term.name: Supervise
term.definition: In reference to restricted-use pesticide application, this means the certified person is "available" if needed. In DoD, this means the non-certified applicator is in line of sight of the certified supervisor. Under the law of most States, "available" means within the metropolitan area.

term.name: Surface gills
term.definition: An organ for respiration under water. In some animals the gills can function in air if they do not become too dry.

term.name: Surface tension
term.definition: A property of liquids that forms cohesive forces near the surface. The surface contracts and has properties similar to stretched elastic. Small particles such as wettable powders will be unable to penetrate the surface. You may recall seeing insects such as water striders walking across a water surface because they don't break the surface tension.

term.name: Surface treatment
term.definition: A brush-on, or spray-on wood preservative treatment that covers the wood surface without penetrating into the wood.

term.name: Surface Waters
term.definition: Include lakes and ponds and rivers, as opposed to ground water, which is literally underground. Pesticides end up in surface water when they wash downhill from application sites or leaky storage buildings into water.

term.name: Surfactant
term.definition: An inert ingredient that improves the spreading, dispersing, and/or wetting properties of a pesticide mixture.

term.name: Surveillance
term.definition: (1) Observing the pesticide problem as a first step towards developing an integrated pest management (IPM) strategy. (2) Thorough inspections or surveys made before or after pest management treatments to determine the presences and prevalence of pests or disease vectors (From DODI 41507, DoD Pest Management Program); Observing the pesticide problem as a first step towards developing an integrated pest management (IPM) strategy.

term.name: Suspension
term.definition: Particles of a solid or unmixable liquid dispersed in a liquid or gas but not dissolved in it.

term.name: Symbiosis
term.definition: The intimate association of two kinds of organisms, like plants and fungi. If both organisms benefit from the association, it is called "Mutualism".

term.name: Symbiotic
term.definition: A relationship of mutual benefit or dependence.

term.name: Synanthropy
term.definition: The urge to live in human settlements shown by domestic or filth flies, as well as other animals.

term.name: Synergist
term.definition: substance used with pesticides to enhance their activity.

term.name: Synthetic organic insecticides
term.definition: Insecticides containing carbon, but developed in the laboratory instead of in the living world.

term.name: Systemic
term.definition: Pertaining to or affecting the entire bodily system or the body as a whole.

term.name: Systemic Foliage Applied Herbicide
term.definition: Slow-acting herbicides that are applied to plant foliage and then absorbed and translocated within the plant, moving through the entire plant, killing the roots.

term.name: Systemic Herbicide
term.definition: Herbicide that is absorbed and translocated within a plant.

term.name: Targeted application
term.definition: a pesticide application aimed directly at the problem pest or its habitat. Targeted application reduces the likelihood of pesticide resistance.

term.name: Taxonomic
term.definition: Pertaining to the identification, naming and classification of organisms

term.name: Telson
term.definition: Specially modified segment at the tip of the last segment (Tail) of a scorpion that contains the venom gland.

term.name: Tending
term.definition: Ant behavior that consists of protecting honeydew-producing insects from predators and sometimes moving them around to better feeding spots on the plant.

term.name: Termite Aggregation Pheromone
term.definition: Termites secrete an aggregation pheromone which is useful in marking paths to food and water sources.

term.name: Thermal Fogging
term.definition: A method of producing ultra-low volume aerosols in which pesticide is atomized into aerosol-sized droplets by means of heat.

term.name: Thigmotaxis
term.definition: Movement of an organism in response to contact with a solid body. Domestic rodents have positive thigmotaxis, meaning they LIKE to touch, especially solid forms like the edge of a wall.

term.name: Thoracic
term.definition: Pertaining to the thorax. In insects and other arthropods the thorax is a body division consisting of several segments lying between the head and abdomen, to which are attached legs or other appendages.

term.name: Threshold planning quantity (TPQ)
term.definition: A baseline amount of an extremely hazardous substances. The baseline is established by federal guidelines. Any facility with extremely hazardous substance in amounts in excess of the threshold planning quantity is required to notify the state commission 60 days after the facility first begins handling an extremely hazardous substance in excess of its TPQ.

term.name: Throttle
term.definition: Controls flow of fuel into engine.

term.name: Toxic
term.definition: Poisonous to living organisms.

term.name: Toxicant
term.definition: A poisonous substance such as the active ingredient in a pesticide formulation.

term.name: Toxicity
term.definition: (1) A chemical's ability to alter a living tissue's metabolism. This is a chemical property of a compound and cannot be modified except by destroying the compound. In this lesson, toxicity is classified according to the EPA system, into toxicity categories. The following terms are used: practically non-toxic, slightly toxic, moderately toxic, and highly toxic. Keep in mind that toxicity can be quite variable within a specific class of insecticides. (2) The degree to which a substance is poisonous. Chemical property of compound; non-conditional (non-controllable characteristic cannot be amended). Toxicity cannot be changed, while exposure can be controlled. If you are not exposed to a highly fatal potent poison safely locked up in a cabinet there is zero risk.

term.name: Toxicity tables (inhalation)
term.definition: Lists the lethal concentration or LC50 of material that may be inhaled from the air. The amount of toxin is expressed as a fraction, milligrams of toxin per kilograms of body weight of a test animal.

term.name: Toxicity tables (oral and dermal)
term.definition: Lists the LD50 or lethal dose for solids and liquids that may be absorbed orally or dermally. The amount of toxin is expressed as a fraction, milligrams of toxin per liter of air or water (parts per million).

term.name: Toxicologists
term.definition: Determine the levels at which pesticides become poisonous to humans and other organisms. Trace the metabolic pathway of pesticidal compounds in humans.

term.name: Toxicology
term.definition: The study of poisons and their effects.

term.name: Traceable pesticides
term.definition: Any pesticidal material used by a pest management professional on a government installation.

term.name: Trachea
term.definition: In the respiratory system of arthropods, any of the small tubules branching throughout the body and conducting air from the exterior

term.name: Tracheids
term.definition: The supporting and water-conducting cells (xylem) found in softwood trees.

term.name: Trachioles
term.definition: Air-conveying tubules forming the respiratory system of most insects, millipedes, centipedes, and many arachnids.

term.name: Trade names
term.definition: Another word for brand names. Trade names are great, and sometimes very colorful, but they change.

term.name: Transgenic Plants
term.definition: Pesticide that inserts genes from other organisms into the plant.

term.name: Translocation
term.definition: The movement of food, water, or mineral solutes from one part of a plant to another.

term.name: Transovarial Passage
term.definition: Transmission of pathogen in an organism (such as a tick) from one generation to the next through the egg.

term.name: Transstadial Passage
term.definition: Transmission of pathogen from one stage of development to the next (e.g., nymphal to adult stage of the tick).

term.name: Tribolium Flour Beetles
term.definition: Beetles belonging to the genus Tribolium. Red flour beetles and confused beetles are Tribolium flour beetles.

term.name: Tritocerebrum
term.definition: The third or posterior division of the arthropod brain. The arthropod "brain," is actually a collection of ganglia compressed into a single organ made up of the: protocerebrum, deuterocerebrum, and tritocerebrum.

term.name: Trophallaxis
term.definition: The regurgitation of food by one animal for another. It is most highly developed in social insects such as ants and termites, in which individual colony members store food in their crops and regularly exchange it with other colony members and larvae to form a sort of communal stomach for the colony. It is also used by some vertebrates, such as birds feeding their young.

term.name: Trophic
term.definition: A group of organisms that occupy the same position in a food chain. For example, all green plants and other organisms capable of photosynthesis, as producers, occupy the first position on the food chain.

term.name: Two-cycle engine
term.definition: An internal combustion engine that fires once for every revolution of the crankshaft. The two cycles are intake/compression and power/exhaust.

term.name: Ultra-Low Dosage Aerosol
term.definition: Indoor space treatment with liquid pesticide in which droplet sizes are between 5-30 microns.

term.name: Ultra-low volume
term.definition: Sprays that are applied at a rate of 0.5 gallons or less per acre or sprays and are applied in their undiluted form. (It may be useful to convert gallons of pesticide that will be sprayed from ultra-low volume equipment into ounces when doing inventory.)

term.name: Ultra-Low Volume (ULV) Aerosol
term.definition: Outdoor space treatment with liquid pesticide in which droplet sizes are between 0.1 - 50 microns and application rates are very low--1/2 gallon of pesticide per acre-or LESS.

term.name: Unclassified Pesticides
term.definition: General use pesticides that are not particularly hazardous to people or the environment when applied as directed. Anybody can buy and apply these, but they are still required to read the label and apply the pesticide in accordance with label instructions. However, for commercial application, the Department of Defense and many States require training and certification to apply these pesticides. Unclassified pesticides will not have any statement about this status.

term.name: Urticating Caterpillar
term.definition: Caterpillars that use urticating (or irritating/stinging) hairs as a defense.

term.name: Urtication
term.definition: Defensive behavior of caterpillars which involves stinging or whipping with nettles.

term.name: UV-A
term.definition: Acronym for ultra-violet radiation A (Alpha) range; the longer wave spectrum of ultra-violet light used in black lights to detect rodent urine. Ultraviolet radiation in the wavelength band of 0.32-0.40 m; a component of the spectrum of solar radiation that can tan human skin or cause redness in sensitive skin.

term.name: Vector
term.definition: An insect or organism that carries a pathogen.

term.name: Vector Competence
term.definition: The ability to transmit a disease from one host to another. For example, body lice are Competent vectors of epidemic typhus, while head lice are unable to transmit the disease and are thus "Incompetent vectors".

term.name: Venomous Insects
term.definition: Snakes, spiders and scorpions, and hymenopterans (wasps, bees, and ants).

term.name: Ventral
term.definition: Pertaining to the belly.

term.name: Vertebrates
term.definition: Animals with a backbone; animals belonging to the kingdom Animalia, phylum Vertebrata

term.name: Vertical barrier
term.definition: Treating soil alongside basement walls or from the top of the slab to the bottom creates a vertical barrier.

term.name: Vesicating
term.definition: (1) To cause or form blisters (2) Causing or forming blisters. The only threat from millipedes is that when handled, they exude a defensive, vesicating liquid that causes the skin to blister. If left alone they will not cause harm.

term.name: Vessels
term.definition: The large diameter supporting and water conducting cells of hardwood trees.

term.name: Vibrissa
term.definition: Rodent whiskers

term.name: Viperidae
term.definition: A family of reptiles in the suborder Serpentes found in Eurasia and Africa; all species are solehoglyphs--with moveable, rectractable front fangs. The fangs (or, more precisely, the maxillae) are laid back with the same action as when a pocket-knife is snapped together.

term.name: Visceral
term.definition: Affecting the viscera or internal organs; as in visceral leishmaniasis, which attacks the internal organs.

term.name: Visceral Leishmaniasis
term.definition: A form of leishmaniasis that attacks the internal organs.

term.name: Viscin
term.definition: A clear, tasteless substance extracted from the sap of the mistletoe

term.name: Warning
term.definition: Human hazard signal word for moderately toxic pesticides.

term.name: Weather Blocks
term.definition: Solid rodenticide bait formulated with paraffin wax or some other stabilizing material so the food stays fresh for months. Can be tied to string and suspended just off the floor or nailed to the wall for rats to eat.

term.name: Weed and feed
term.definition: Fertilizer + pre-emergent herbicide mix.

term.name: Wet boom
term.definition: a type of boom that carries liquid. Comprised of pipes with holes drilled at regular spaces. Nozzles are fitted into the holes.

term.name: Wettable powder
term.definition: A dry pesticide formulation in powder form which forms a suspension when added to water.

term.name: Wetting agent
term.definition: A wetting agent is a material similar to soap or detergent. It decreases the toxicant.

term.name: Worker
term.definition: A sterile termite caste that performs most of the colony maintenance, cares for other castes, and eats most of the wood.

term.name: Workload Definition Worksheet
term.definition: Document kept for each pest found on the installation that lists the type of damage caused and control strategies. (If there are 40 pests, there will be 40 separate workload definition worksheets.)

term.name: WP, W, or WWP
term.definition: Wettable powder. As in Decathlon WP

term.name: WSC, SC, or L
term.definition: Water soluble concentrate, a pesticide formulation that dissolves in water.

term.name: WSP
term.definition: Water soluble packet (as in Merit 75 WSP).

term.name: Xylem
term.definition: The supporting and water-conducting tissues of vascular plants. (Xylem cells take different forms depending on the type of plant. For example, hardwood trees have large-diameter xylem cells called "vessels", whereas softwood trees have small-diameter xylem cells called "Tracheids".

term.name: Zoonosis
term.definition: Disease that affects both humans and animals, such as: Leishmaniasis, African Sleeping Sickness, Tularemia, Oropouche, Anthrax.

term.name: Zoonotic Diseases
term.definition: Diseases that under natural conditions are communicable from animals to humans, such as histoplasmosis, psittacosis and rabies.
